<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PSMT" SIZE=2>
<B>
<EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<A NAME="FIS_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES"></A>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<U>
	CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES
</U>
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PSMT">
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Disclosure controls and procedures are defined by
	the Securities and Exchange Commission as those controls and procedures that are
	designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in the
	reports we submit under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded,
	processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the
	Securities and Exchange Commission&#146;s rules and forms. Our Chief Executive
	Officer and Chief Financial Officer have evaluated our disclosure controls and
	procedures and have determined that such disclosure controls and procedures are
	effective as of December 31, 2006.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The design of any system of controls and
	procedures is based in part upon certain assumptions about the likelihood of
	future events. There can be no assurance that any design will succeed in
	achieving its stated goals under all potential future conditions, regardless of
	how remote.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PSMT" SIZE=2>
<B>
<EFX_AUDIT_COMMITTEE_EXPERT>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDIT_COMMITTEE_EXPERT"></A>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<U>
	AUDIT COMMITTEE FINANCIAL EXPERT
</U>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our Board of Directors has determined that it has at least one
	audit committee financial expert serving on its audit committee. Mr. Pierre
	Dupuis has been determined to be such audit committee financial expert. The
	Securities and Exchange Commission has indicated that the designation of Mr.
	Dupuis as an audit committee financial expert does not make Mr. Dupuis an
	"expert" for any purpose, impose any duties, obligations or liability on Mr.
	Dupuis that are greater than those imposed on members of the audit committee and
	board of directors who do not carry this designation or affect the duties,
	obligations or liability of any other member of the audit committee. He is
	independent as that term is defined for purposes of the audit committee member
	independence requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
</EFX_AUDIT_COMMITTEE_EXPERT>
<A NAME="eolPage4"></A>

<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<U>

</U>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Disclosure of off-balance sheet arrangements is made in Note 12
	to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, contained herein.
</P>
</EFX_OFF_BALANCE_SHEET_ARRANGEMENTS>
<B>
<EFX_CODE_OF_ETHICS>
<A NAME="FIS_CODE_OF_ETHICS"></A>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<U>
	CODE OF ETHICS
</U>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Board of Directors of the Corporation has approved, and
	acts in accordance with, the Corporation&#146;s Code of Business Conduct (the
	"Code"). All employees with supervisory responsibilities, members of the
	management team, and each Director have signed the Code. A copy of this Code can
	be found on the Corporation&#146;s web site at www.norbord.com.
</P>
</EFX_CODE_OF_ETHICS>
<B>
<EFX_ACCOUNTANT_FEES>
<A NAME="FIS_ACCOUNTANT_FEES"></A>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<U>
	PRINCIPAL ACCOUNTING FIRM FEES
</U>
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PS">
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Ernst &amp; Young LLP was the Corporation&#146;s
	independent auditor in 2006 and 2005. In addition to audit services, Ernst &amp;
	Young LLP also provided non-audit services to the Corporation and its
	subsidiaries. It is the Corporation&#146;s policy not to engage its auditors to
	provide services in connection with financial information systems design and
	implementation of other services that may impair the objectivity of the
	auditors. The Corporation has implemented a procedure to ensure that any
	engagement of the auditors for non-audit services receives prior clearance by
	the Audit Committee. In approving any such engagement, the Audit Committee will
	consider whether the provision of such non-audit services is compatible with
	maintaining auditor independence.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The table below summarizes the fees paid to Ernst
	&amp; Young LLP in 2005 and 2006:
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>

<TD WIDTH=621>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PSMT" SIZE=2>

<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PSMT">
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Descriptions of the services performed are
	provided below:
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Audit services include the annual financial
	statement audit of the Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries. The fees
	include the review of the Corporation&#146;s unaudited interim financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Audit-related services include audits of the
	Corporation&#146;s pension plans, special purpose nonstatutory audits of divisions of
	the Corporation, comfort letters associated with regulatory filings and internal
	control reviews.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Taxation services include tax advisory and
	compliance services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Other services include expatriate consulting and
	other business advisory services.
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage5"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN PS" SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Auditor Independence
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Ernst &amp; Young LLP has advised the Audit Committee that it
	considers itself to be independent of the Corporation, and the Audit Committee
	has confirmed that it considers Ernst &amp; Young LLP to be independent
</P>
</EFX_ACCOUNTANT_FEES>

<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage6"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=825 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDF401.JPG" WIDTH=769 BORDER=0>
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage7"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<B>
<FONT FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Norbord Inc. is an international producer of wood-based
	panels with assets of $1.3 billion. We employ approximately 2,800 people at 16
	plant locations in the United States, Europe and Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<DIR>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	We are one of the world&#146;s largest producers of oriented
	strand board (OSB).
</FONT>
</P>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	In addition to OSB, we manufacture particleboard, medium
	density fibreboard (MDF), hardwood plywood and related value-added
	products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Norbord is a publicly traded company listed on the TSX
	under the symbol NBD.
</FONT>
</P>
</DIR>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH="5%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	(1)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=JUSTIFY WIDTH="95%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	At December 31, 2006, the Board of Directors had
	declared 65 consecutive quarterly common dividends of CAD $0.10 per
	share.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH="5%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	(2)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=JUSTIFY WIDTH="95%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	Norbord paid a special dividend of CAD $1.00 per share
	in each of the past three years. The special dividends were declared to
	preserve an efficient capital structure through the peak of the OSB price
	cycle.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN=TOP WIDTH="5%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	(3)
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=JUSTIFY WIDTH="95%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
	Distribution of shares of Fraser Papers to common
	shareholders valued using Fraser Papers&#146; closing price on July 7,
	2004.
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">

<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P>
	To Our Shareholders
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=RIEGOY+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<I>
<P>
	J. Barrie Shineton
<BR>
	President and Chief Executive
	Officer
</P>
</I>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	2006 Highlights
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="RIEGOY+FRANKLIN GOTHIC" SIZE=2>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	RECORDED EARNINGS OF $97 MILLION OR $0.67 PER SHARE
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	ACHIEVED 25% RETURN ON CAPITAL EMPLOYED
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	ACHIEVED 20% RETURN ON EQUITY
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord delivered earnings of $97 million or $0.67 per share
	and a return on equity of 20% in 2006. We paid a third consecutive CAD $1.00 per
	share special dividend and repurchased 2.7 million common shares. These actions
	demonstrate our confidence in Norbord's low cost position and ability to
	generate attractive cash flow throughout the business cycle. Our strategy of
	geographic diversification was validated as markets for our North American and
	European products headed in different directions during 2006.
</P>
<FONT FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Weaker North American Markets
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	After several robust years, North American OSB prices declined
	steadily during 2006 to their lowest levels since 2001. The decline was in
	response to softer US housing starts, a scenario we fully expected. On the
	supply side, significant new OSB capacity will ramp up over the next two years.
	Both will keep pressure on prices for the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Our strategy of owning only low-cost
	assets and aligning ourselves with growth customers paid off in the second half
	of the year when prices dropped below trend levels. All our OSB mills generated
	positive cash flow and were able to sell all their production volume. The result
	is that every mill is running at full capacity with no inventory buildup.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2006, we completed the
	expansion of the Cordele, Georgia OSB mill. We started up the second line on
	time and on budget in December. In the absence of attractive acquisition
	opportunities, this project was a unique and logical opportunity for Norbord to
	continue its record of controlled growth in low-cost OSB capacity. The workforce
	for the second line trained alongside their experienced colleagues on the
	existing line and they are well prepared to ramp up to full capacity very
	quickly. Once ramped up, Cordele will be Norbord&#146;s largest and lowest-cost OSB
	mill, further improving the Company's overall cost position.
</P>
<FONT FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Improving European Performance
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	European markets and prices are firming as a result of the
	significant improvement in the supply-demand balance across the region and the
	general strengthening of the continental European economy. In Germany,
	construction activity and investment is growing for the first time this
	decade.&nbsp; We've been successful in focusing Norbord's
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	particleboard sales on the
	construction sector, where about 75% of our European panel production is now
	directed. We experienced stronger demand and pricing across all our product
	lines during 2006. Although increases in selling prices were offset by higher
	input costs, particularly for resin and energy, operating cash flow improved due
	to our efforts to increase production volume and control raw material usage.
	Moreover, improving markets means customers are accepting both the pass-through
	of cost increases and the recovery of producers&#146; margins.
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>

	REPORT

</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;

</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>

	3
</FONT>
</P>

</TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<P>
	2006 Highlights
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<UL>
<LI>
	RECORDED EBITDA OF $247 MILLION
<LI>
	PAID THIRD SPECIAL DIVIDEND OF CAD $1.00/SHARE OR $128 MILLION
<LI>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	BOUGHT BACK 2.7 MILLION COMMON
	SHARES FOR $29 MILLION
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	Energy cost increases will be mitigated
	by the biomass heat energy system commissioned at our Cowie, Scotland operation
	in November and by a similar but larger project at our Genk, Belgium operation
	to be commissioned in the fourth quarter of 2007. These investments will reduce
	our European natural gas usage by about one-third &#150; a great example of how we
	are getting more control over input costs.
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	Focus on Cost Position
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	We spent the last three years preparing our business to prosper
	through the down cycle by focusing on costs and improving product mix. We
	believe we&#146;ve strengthened our competitive position by increasing our operating
	rates, reducing raw material usage and minimizing our reliance on natural gas.
	Being low-cost is vital as we believe it is the only way to ensure positive cash
	flow during weaker markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	Our Margin Improvement Program (MIP),
	implemented in 1996,remains the cornerstone of Norbord&#146;s efforts to "control the
	controllables." Selling a richer product mix and producing more volume from
	existing capacity were the biggest drivers of our 2006 MIP savings of $56
	million. Put another way, our EBITDA would have been significantly lower with
	out our MIP efforts.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	An important example of our cost control
	efforts is our investment in biomass heat energy systems.&nbsp; Once projects
	currently underway at Nacogdoches, Texas, and Genk are complete, all our OSB
	process heat will come from wood waste, and we will only use natural gas for air
	emission control equipment.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON SIZE=3>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">

<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON>
<B>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<P>
	2006 Highlights
</P>
</FONT>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<UL>
<LI>
	GENERATED $56 MILLION
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	IN MARGIN IMPROVEMENTS
<LI>
	STARTED UP SECOND OSB LINE AT CORDELE, GEORGIA
<LI>
	ACHIEVED RECORD ANNUAL OSB PRODUCTION
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Another example of cost containment is our streamlining of
	production capacity in Europe. We closed smaller, obsolete capacity and
	consolidated production on our newer, more efficient lines at our South Molton,
	England, and Cowie mills. We&#146;ve already seen significant gains in production
	from the consolidated lines and expect these actions will result in higher
	overall margin contribution from our European business.
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Strategy Unchanged
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We continue to believe OSB is the industry&#146;s best growth
	opportunity and that successful execution of our strategy will maximize value
	for our shareholders. Our strategy is simple and straightforward, and delivers
	results.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2006, we made excellent
	progress against our objectives:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Grow
	our OSB business
</B>
	&#150;We achieved record annual OSB production with a 4%
	increase over 2005 and started up a second line at our Cordele OSB mill on time
	and on budget.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	2.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Own high-quality,
	well-located assets with industry-leading cost positions
</B>
	&#150; We installed a
	biomass heat energy system at our Cowie mill, approved similar projects at Genk
	and Nacogdoches, and streamlined existing European production capacity by
	closing two older, less efficient lines.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	3.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Maintain a margin-focused
	operating culture
</B>
	&#150;We generated $56 million in margin improvements, more
	than off setting the impact of higher resin and energy prices on our input
	costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	4.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Focus on customers who are
	growing their own market share
</B>
	&#150;We increased North American OSB sales volume
	with key big box customers and secured new long-term panelboard business with
	leading UK home builders.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	5.
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Allocate capital with
	discipline
</B>
	&#150;We returned $157 million to shareholders through a special
	dividend and share repurchases and invested $160 million in low-risk,
	high-return capital projects.
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<P>
	2006 Highlights
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<UL>
<LI>
	STREAMLINED EUROPEAN PRODUCTION CAPACITY
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	REDUCED DIRECT GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS BY 23%
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	STARTED UP BIOMASS HEAT ENERGY SYSTEM AT COWIE, SCOTLAND
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Workplace Safety and the Environment
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We are committed to protecting our employees, the environment
	and the communities in which we operate. Last year, we set aggressive targets to
	help us meet our objectives of improving safety performance, working towards
	full compliance with environmental regulations, and minimizing our operations&#146;
	impact on the environment. While I&#146;m pleased to report continued progress
	towards these objectives during 2006, a fatal incident late in the year
	reinforced the urgency of our actions to improve workplace safety. I invite you
	to review the Environment, Health and Safety Report included in the annual
	report to learn more about how we are managing these areas to ensure the
	long-term sustainability of our business.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Looking Ahead
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Looking to 2007, we expect that our North American and European
	business results will continue to diverge. Continued weak US housing starts
	combined with the ramp-up of new capacity will keep North American OSB prices
	soft. Without additional closures of structural panel capacity, we don&#146;t expect
	to see much price improvement. On the other hand, we anticipate further
	strengthening of demand in Europe and continued improvement in prices for our
	panel products. We also expect some moderation in the excessively high resin and
	energy prices experienced in Europe last year. While the diversification
	provided by our European business will not replace the reduced cash flow from
	our North American business, we believe it will help cushion the Company&#146;s
	results through the bottom of the cycle.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Longer term, the fundamentals
	underpinning demand for structural panels remain compelling. Supportive
	demographics, increasing two-home ownership, larger house sizes, record turnover
	of homes and the aging of existing housing stock will ultimately return North
	American OSB demand to trend levels. In Europe, evolving homebuilding practices
	and the emergence of eastern European economic growth will keep panel demand
	growing at a healthy pace.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=QAUAAA+ACASLON>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>

<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON>
<B>
<P>
	2006 Highlights
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	COMMENCED INSTALLATION OF BIOMASS HEAT ENERGY SYSTEMS IN GENK,
	BELGIUM AND NACOGDOCHES, TEXAS
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	INCREASED NORTH AMERICAN OSB SALES VOLUME WITH KEY BIG BOX
	CUSTOMERS
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	SECURED NEW LONG-TERM PANEL-BOARD BUSINESS WITH LEADING UK HOME
	BUILDERS
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord has a strong balance sheet
	and significant liquidity. This, combined with our low cost position, leaves
	Norbord well positioned to weather the down cycle in North American OSB and
	benefit quickly when prices improve.
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Transitions
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As previously reported, Don Wells, our Director and Audit
	Committee Chair, passed away in August. During his three-year tenure on our
	Board, Don&#146;s financial acumen and wisdom were highly valued and he made a
	lasting contribution to our company for the benefit of all shareholders.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Creating Long-Term Shareholder
	Value
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord continues to focus on maximizing shareholder value.
	Norbord stock has provided a
	19%compoundannualtotalreturntoshareholdersoverthepast five years, about half of
	this as cash dividends. We believe you will continue to be rewarded for your
	investment in Norbord throughout the business cycle.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On behalf of the entire Norbord team,
	thank you for your continued support.
</P>

<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_2"></A>
<P>
<B>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Management's Discussion and
	Analysis
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Fiscal Year 2006
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<I>
<P>
	January 31, 2007
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Management's Discussion and Analysis (MD&amp;A) provides a
	review of the significant developments that impacted Norbord's performance
	during 2006 relative to 2005. Some of the statements included or incorporated by
	reference in this MD&amp;A constitute forward-looking statements within the
	meaning of applicable securities legislation. Forward-looking statements are
	based on various assumptions and are subject to various risks. See the
	cautionary statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements section.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	To enhance shareholders' understanding, certain five-year
	historical financial and statistical information is presented. Norbord's
	significant accounting policies and other financial disclosures are contained in
	the audited financial statements and accompanying notes. All financial
	references in the MD&amp;A are stated in US dollars unless otherwise noted.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Certain historical financial and statistical information for
	the years 2004, 2003 and 2002 include information for the paper and timberlands
	business (Fraser Papers), which was distributed to Norbord's common shareholders
	on June 30, 2004, and thus may not be comparable with the information for the
	years 2006 and 2005.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	EBITDA, EBITDA margin, operating working capital, total working
	capital, capital employed, ROCE, ROE, net debt, net debt to capitalization, book
	basis, net debt to capitalization, market basis and book value per share are
	non-GAAP measures described in the Definitions section. Non-GAAP measures do not
	have any standardized meaning prescribed by GAAP and are therefore unlikely to
	be comparable to similar measures presented by other companies. There are no
	directly comparable GAAP measures to any of these measures. Where appropriate, a
	quantitative reconciliation of the non-GAAP measure to the nearest comparable
	GAAP measure is also provided.
</P>
<P>
	Additional information on Norbord, including the annual information form, is
	available on SEDAR at www.sedar.com.
</P>
</I>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_3"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage17"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Management's
	Discussion and Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	10
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Business Overview
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord is an international producer of wood-based panels, with
	16 plant locations in the United States, Europe and Canada. It is one of the
	world's largest producers of oriented strand board (OSB) with annual capacity of
	5.0 billion square feet (
<SUP>
	3
</SUP>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/8
</FONT>
	-inch basis). The
	core of Norbord's OSB business is located in the US South. The Company is a
	significant producer of wood-based panels in Europe. Norbord does not own any
	timberlands. It purchases wood fibre from third parties that include private
	landowners and government-owned timberlands. Norbord employed approximately
	2,800 people at December 31, 2006.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Operations include 11 OSB mills, 3
	particleboard plants, 2 medium density fibreboard (MDF) plants, 1 hardwood
	plywood mill, 1 I-joist mill, 2 laminating operations, and a furniture plant.
	The Company reports all operations as a single operating segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord's OSB and particleboard
	panels are used primarily in the construction sector and its MDF and hardwood
	plywood panels serve the furniture and fixtures markets.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>

<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Strategy
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord's business strategy is focused entirely on the wood
	panels sector &#150; in particular OSB &#150; in North America and Europe.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX">
	The Company's overall business strategy focuses on
	five key areas:
</P>
<OL>
<LI>
	Pursuing growth in OSB through optimization or expansion of existing
	assets and opportunistic acquisitions.
<LI>
	Owning high-quality, well-located assets with industry-leading cost
	positions.
<LI>
	Maintaining a margin-focused operating culture.
<LI>
	Focusing customer service strategy on customers who are growing their own
	market share.
<LI>
	Maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation.
</LI>
</OL>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_4"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage18"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
	Management's Discussion and
	Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL
	REPORT
<BR>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	11
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is of the view that successful execution of this
	strategy will result in superior shareholder returns. Good progress was made in
	each of the strategic elements during the year, including the following
	highlights:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
	Started up $135 million expansion project at Cordele, Georgia OSB mill on
	time and on budget
<LI>
	Achieved record annual OSB production &#150; a 4% increase over 2005
<LI>
	Streamlined European production capacity by decommissioning older, less
	efficient particleboard and MDF lines
<LI>
	Started up a new biomass heat energy system in Cowie, Scotland
<LI>
	Commenced installation of new biomass energy systems at Genk, Belgium and
	Nacogdoches, Texas
<LI>
	Improved European earnings trend
<LI>
	Generated $56 million in margin improvements
<LI>
	Expanded North American OSB sales volume with key big box customers
<LI>
	Secured new panelboard business with leading UK home builders
<LI>
	Paid third CAD $1.00 special dividend, in addition to the regular CAD
	$0.10 quarterly dividend
<LI>
	Completed the repurchase of 2.7 million common shares
<LI>
	Completed small shareholder buyback program
</LI>
</UL>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord's financial goal is to achieve top quartile return on
	equity (ROE) and cash return on capital employed (ROCE) among North American
	forest products companies. Norbord believes that it has met this target in each
	of the past four years.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Maintaining investment grade debt
	ratings is an important element of Norbord's financing strategy. With investment
	grade debt ratings, Norbord believes that it should have the benefit of
	long-term access to public and private capital markets on attractive terms.
	Ratings on Norbord debt have been consistently investment grade since 1992.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord manages its business to
	provide for a sustainable dividend to be paid quarterly to common shareholders
	throughout the business cycle, subject to Board approval. At December 31, 2006,
	the Board of Directors had declared 65 consecutive quarterly common dividends of
	CAD $0.10 per share. In addition, Norbord paid three special dividends of CAD
	$1.00 per share to common shareholders in each of the past three years. The
	special dividends were declared to preserve an efficient capital structure
	through the peak of the OSB price cycle.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>

<TD WIDTH="43%">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<I>
<B>
	Net Sales and
	Earnings
</B>
</I>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Fluctuation in the price of North American OSB is the most
	significant driver of changes in Norbord's results. Results in 2006 were
	negatively impacted by the steady decline in North American OSB prices &#150; from
	$320 per Msf (North Central
<SUP>
	7
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/16
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	-inch basis) at the beginning of the year to $158 per Msf at the end of
	the year, averaging $217 per Msf. Benchmark prices decreased from 2005 average
	prices of $320 per Msf in response to a slowing of US housing starts from 2005's
	record levels, as speculators and investors withdrew from the housing market and
	builders reacted to higher home inventories. A decline was fully expected, but
	the retreat from the highs seen in the past few years was earlier and deeper
	than anticipated.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">

	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.

<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_6"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage20"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 HEIGHT=94 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%" HEIGHT=15>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
	Management's Discussion and
	Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2 HEIGHT=15>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD WIDTH="68%" HEIGHT=42>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%" HEIGHT=42>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP: 0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0PX; MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%" HEIGHT=42>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%" HEIGHT=37>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2 HEIGHT=37>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	13
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=262 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG4.GIF" WIDTH=876 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Throughout the cycle, Norbord took steps to prepare itself for
	this inevitable downturn by focusing on cost containment and by focusing product
	mix on higher margin products. The Margin Improvement Program (MIP) has helped
	Norbord to concentrate on improving its competitive position, generating over
	$185 million of savings in the past five years, including $56 million in 2006.
	These gains have helped to offset the impact of industry-wide rising input costs
	and management believes its relative competitive position has improved over this
	time. The benefit of the discipline exercised through the top of the cycle is
	that all Norbord mills generated positive EBITDA in the second half of the year
	when North American OSB prices traded well below the historical
	average.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=261 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG5.GIF" WIDTH=861 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In contrast to North America, markets in Europe showed steady
	improvement during 2006 as the economy expanded, particularly in Germany where
	construction activity and investment are growing for the first time this decade.
	Norbord's European business is exposed to different market dynamics than the
	North American business. The Company believes this provides meaningful earnings
	diversification, while capitalizing on Norbord's strength as a panel
	producer.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_7"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage21"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Management's
	Discussion and Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	14
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	EBITDA of $247 million was generated in 2006 versus a very
	strong $495 million in 2005. EBITDA margins were 20%, compared to 34% for the
	prior year. 2006 earnings were $97 million, or $0.67 per share, versus $248
	million, or $1.61 per share, in 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Return on equity (ROE) was 20% in
	2006 compared to 46% in 2005. ROE is a measure for shareholders to determine how
	effectively their money is being employed. Capital initiatives, including the
	three CAD $1.00 special dividends paid in each of the past three years and the
	share repurchase program, have maintained the efficiency of Norbord's capital
	structure and contributed to the high ROE levels. The 2004 and prior ROE
	includes Fraser Papers, which was distributed to common shareholders in the
	third quarter of 2004. Pre-tax return on capital employed (ROCE) averaged 25%
	for the year compared to 53% in 2005. ROCE is a measurement of financial
	performance, focusing on cash generation and the efficient use of
	capital.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=234 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG6.GIF" WIDTH=435 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord achieved record annual OSB
	production in 2006, increasing volume 4% over 2005 levels. OSB volume has more
	than doubled over the past five years, growing at a compound annual rate of 19%.
	Producing more volume from existing assets has contributed to Norbord's cost
	containment efforts. Norbord's OSB production is expected to increase by more
	than 10% in 2007, as a result of the ramp-up of the second line at Cordele and
	productivity improvements at existing mills.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash provided by operating activities
	totalled $191 million or $1.33 per share in 2006. In the past five years, over
	$1.4 billion in cash has been generated from operating activities. This cash has
	been used to reshape the Company from a traditional Canadian forest products
	company to a focused internationally-recognized leader in the structural panels
	sector. During this time, Norbord has:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
	Invested $610 million in growing the business
<LI>
	Reduced net debt and preferred shares outstanding by $160 million
<LI>
	Paid out $550 million in cash dividends
<LI>
	Invested $100 million to repurchase 10.2 million common shares
<LI>
	Distributed paper and timberlands business (Fraser Papers) to shareholders
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=260 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG7.GIF" WIDTH=476 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	This transformation has contributed to strong returns for
	shareholders. A CAD $100 investment in Norbord shares at the end of 2001 would
	have grown to CAD $234 by the end of 2006, assuming reinvestment of dividends
	and other distributions, representing a compound annual return of 19% per year.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>

<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>

</B>
</FONT>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	67

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Markets
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	North American OSB accounts for two-thirds of Norbord's panel
	shipments by volume, therefore results of operations are most affected by
	volatility in the price of North American OSB. Comprising almost 30% of
	shipments by volume, the relative strength of European panel markets also
	affects results, although to a much lesser degree. North America is the
	principal market destination for Norbord's products.
</P>
</FONT>

</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_9"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage23"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Management's
	Discussion and Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	16
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	New home construction is the primary end use for OSB in North
	America, accounting for about 70% of OSB demand. US housing starts for 2006 were
	1.8 million following 2.1 million in 2005, the highest annual level of starts
	since 1972. The long anticipated housing downturn unfolded more sharply than
	expected despite a relatively strong economic backdrop.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Interest rates and inflation in North
	America remained relatively low while GDP growth and consumer confidence
	remained relatively strong. Thirty-year US mortgage rates averaged 6.4% in 2006
	compared to 5.9% in 2005. Most indicators suggest that the underlying
	demographics, driven by immigration, will continue to support a high level of
	housing demand throughout the coming decade. Canadian housing starts increased
	1% over 2005 and remain robust at 0.2 million units.
</P>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=249 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG9.GIF" WIDTH=413 BORDER=0>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The North American structural panel
	industry produced 42 billion square feet (
<SUP>
	3
</SUP>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/8
</FONT>
	-inch basis) of panels in 2006. OSB production reached 26
	billion square feet in 2006 and now represents approximately 62% of total North
	American structural panel production. Industry-wide OSB production was up 1%
	over 2005 while plywood production decreased 6%.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The North Central benchmark OSB price
	averaged $217 per Msf (
<SUP>
	7
</SUP>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/16
</FONT>
	-inch basis) in 2006
	compared to an average price of $320 per Msf in the prior year. Regional pricing
	variations, particularly in the US South, make the North Central benchmark price
	a useful, albeit imperfect, proxy for over-all North American OSB pricing.
	Further, the pricing lag effect of maintaining an order file, premiums obtained
	on value-added products, and volume and trade discounts cause realized prices to
	differ from the benchmark. Norbord's realized OSB prices or mill nets (net sales
	divided by shipments) were 102% of the benchmark in 2006 and 97% in 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	European markets showed steady
	improvement during 2006 as European construction market confidence improved,
	particularly in Germany. As a result, European OSB prices increased 5% over 2005
	and averaged 8% above the five-year average.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company believes that improvement
	in the European economy in 2006 led to higher demand and prices for
	particleboard and MDF. Furthermore, Norbord successfully expanded particleboard
	sales to the construction sector, a focus selected to maximize synergies with
	its OSB sales strategy. While European results benefited from the higher price
	levels, these gains were tempered by continued high energy, resin and other
	input costs.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>

</TD>

	&nbsp;

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Net Sales
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="3%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Shipments
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Eight of Norbord's 11 OSB mills established annual production
	records in 2006. Improvements delivered as a result of implementing best
	practices resulted in a 4% production increase. This follows a 9% increase in
	OSB production in 2005. Particleboard production increased 2% as compared to
	2005 despite decommissioning the older and less efficient particleboard line at
	South Molton, England in the third quarter of 2006. The decrease in MDF
	production as compared to 2005 is the result of decommissioning the older MDF
	line at Cowie in the second quarter of 2006. Norbord's total European MDF
	production is expected to return to about 90% of its pre-closure volume by the
	end of 2007 as production at the remaining MDF facility is optimized.
</P>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Operating Results
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, EBITDA was $247 million as compared with $495 million
	in 2005. The primary driver of the change in EBITDA was the lower North American
	OSB price. Benchmark OSB prices in 2006 averaged 32% below the highs seen in
	2005 and 20% below the five-year average. The components of the EBITDA change
	are summarized in the following variance table. EBITDA margin was 20% compared
	to 34% for the prior year.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=221 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG10.GIF" WIDTH=748 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The mill
	net variance represents the change in realized pricing across all products. Mill
	net is calculated as net sales divided by shipment volume.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Key
	inputs include fibre, resin and energy.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	(3)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The
	volume variance represents the impact of shipment volume changes across all
	products.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	(4)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other
	category comprises all remaining variances including labour and benefits,
	supplies and maintenance, the impact of foreign exchange, and the $7 million
	refund of softwood lumber duty received in the fourth quarter of 2006.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	North American OSB generated EBITDA of $215 million (2005 &#150;
	$478 million). Other products contributed $41 million (2005 &#150; $35 million) to
	EBITDA. These figures exclude unallocated corporate overhead relating to all
	product lines totalling $16 million (2005 &#150; $18 million) and softwood lumber
	duty refunds of $7 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The global forest products industry
	continued to be challenged with significantly higher key input prices in 2006.
	The prices of energy, resin and fibre, which account for approximately 70% of
	production costs, have each increased more than 70% in the past five years. In
	2006, while the rate of increase diminished, all of these input prices increased
	over 2005. Gains from the Margin Improvement Program (MIP) of $56 million in
	2006, measured relative to 2005 at constant prices and exchange rates, limited
	the impact these higher input prices had on earnings. Mix, volume and key input
	usage initiatives were the largest contributors to MIP in 2006. Globally,
	Norbord expects to deliver MIP of $45 million for the full year 2007.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=235 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDPAG11.GIF" WIDTH=434 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Despite these continued input price
	pressures, Norbord's North American per unit OSB production costs, before
	employee profit share, were in line with the prior year &#150; the result of
	increased productivity and improved raw material usages.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The direct impact on operating costs
	of rising energy prices has been limited as the majority of Norbord's energy is
	provided by burning bark and other biomass. Natural gas and electricity satisfy
	the remainder of Norbord's energy requirements. The Company estimates the
	unfavourable impact of a $1 per mmbtu increase in the price of natural gas to
	negatively impact annual earnings by approximately $3 million, or less
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	than 2 cents per share. Norbord
	continues to look for ways to improve its level of energy self-sufficiency. For
	example, the energy system at Cowie (operational November 2006) and energy
	systems at Genk and Nacogdoches (both scheduled to be operational fourth quarter
	2007) should eliminate the use of natural gas to generate process heat across
	the Company's OSB operations.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>

	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>

<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_12"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage26"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
	Management's Discussion and
	Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	19
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Net sales were $1,252 million,
	compared to $1,462 million in 2005. The impact on net sales of higher shipment
	volumes was offset by lower North American OSB prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	EBITDA margins for non-OSB products
	averaged 6% in 2006 compared to 7% in 2005. MDF and particleboard costs were
	impacted by energy and resin price pressures. MDF and particleboard are more
	energy- and resin-intensive products than OSB.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Depreciation expense increased $5
	million in 2006 to $94 million, due to the impact of recent capital investments.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Interest and Income Tax
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Interest expense of $29 million in 2006 was down from $30
	million in 2005. Interest of $7 million was capitalized in 2006 relating to the
	Cordele expansion completed in December. This offset the impact that higher
	average debt levels and increased short-term interest rates had on interest
	expense. Long-term debt ended the year at $480 million, up from $440 million at
	December 31, 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The effective interest rate on
	Norbord's debt-related obligations, including the impact of interest rate swaps,
	was 7.7% at December 31, 2006, compared to 7.2% at year-end 2005. Approximately
	80% of Norbord's net debt was subject to floating interest rates during the
	year. The increased average rate was the result of higher US money market rates
	in 2006.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	From time to time the Company
	recoupons its portfolio of interest rate swaps to more efficiently manage cash
	flow and credit exposure. Any gains realized are deferred and amortized over the
	remaining term of the debt against which the swaps were designated as hedges. At
	December 31, 2006, $19 million of gains were deferred and included in accounts
	payable and accrued liabilities and other liabilities in the consolidated
	balance sheet. The amortization of $8 million in 2006 and $8 million in 2005 was
	included in interest expense. Interest income in 2006 amounted to $3 million
	compared to $5 million in 2005. Interest earned on cash and cash equivalents
	accounts for the majority of interest income. A tax expense of $17 million was
	recorded in 2006 on pre-tax earnings of $114 million. The effective tax rate of
	15% is less than the statutory rate of 34% principally due to rate differences
	on foreign activities.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At December 31, 2006, the Company had
	tax operating loss carryforwards of approximately &#163;36 million from UK operations
	that can be carried forward indefinitely. The Company has capital losses in
	Canada of CAD $66 million that can also be carried forward indefinitely. The
	Company also has approximately CAD $34 million of investment tax credits (ITCs)
	available to reduce future Canadian tax liabilities. The ITCs expire between
	2007 and 2014. The loss carryforwards and the credits may be utilized over the
	next several years to eliminate cash taxes otherwise payable, and will enhance
	future cash flows. The future tax benefits of these temporary differences have
	been included in future income taxes in the consolidated financial
	statements.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>

	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>

<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 11PX">
	67
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash provided by operating activities was $191 million, or
	$1.33 per share, compared to $314 million, or $2.14 per share, in 2005. Changes
	in earnings is the principal driver of changes in cash provided by operating
	activities. Higher cash taxes in 2006 and 2005 following the utilization of the
	majority of the benefit of the North American tax operating loss carryforwards
	in 2004 also contributed to the lower level of cash provided by operating
	activities in these years.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Operating working capital, consisting
	of accounts receivable and inventory less accounts payable and accrued
	liabilities was $33 million at December 31,2006, compared to $19 million at
	December 31,2005. A higher accounts receivable balance due to an increase in
	non-trade receivables is the primary driver of the change in the operating
	working capital balance. Collections of trade receivables are in line with prior
	periods. The Company aims to minimize the amount of capital held as operating
	working capital. Total working capital at December 31,2006 was $53 million
	including $20 million in cash and cash equivalents. Total working capital is
	down significantly over 2005 principally due to the lower cash balance in
	2006.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In addition to cash on hand and cash
	generated from operations, the Company has $200 million of committed unsecured
	revolving bank lines available to support short-term liquidity requirements, of
	which $44 million were utilized at December 31, 2006 &#150; $40 million drawn as cash
	and $4 million drawn for letters of credit. These committed bank lines mature in
	2010, bear interest at money market rates plus a margin that varies with the
	Company's credit rating, and contain certain financial covenants which the
	Company must comply with on a quarterly basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash dividends of $167 million or CAD
	$1.40 per share were paid in the year including the payment of a CAD $1.00
	special dividend on July 14, 2006, the third special dividend in the past three
	years. Dividends were funded with cash from operations. Other uses of the cash
	from operations in the year include $160 million for capital investments and $29
	million for common share repurchases. These initiatives are discussed in further
	detail in the Investments and Divestitures and Capitalization sections. In
	addition, $40 million of cash was received through the drawdown of the committed
	bank lines, which is reflected as an increase in long-term debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord's net debt stood at $460
	million at year-end, representing 27% of capitalization on a market basis and
	51% of capitalization on a book basis. Net debt includes long-term debt of $480
	million less cash and cash equivalents of $20 million.
</P>
</FONT>

	$365 million (2005 &#150; $365 million) of interest rate swaps outstanding, and 84%

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 35PX; TEXT-INDENT: -35PX">
	Note: The above table does not
	include pension and post-retirement benefits plan obligations which are
	discussed in the Significant Accounting Policies and Estimates &#150; Defined Benefit
	Pension Plans section.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Investments and Divestitures
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Capital Investments
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In December 2006, the second OSB line at Cordele was completed,
	on time and on budget, creating one of the largest and most efficient OSB
	manufacturing facilities in the world. The expansion added approximately 550
	million square feet (
<SUP>
	3
</SUP>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/8
</FONT>
	-inch basis) of
	production capacity at a capital cost of $135 million and increased Norbord's
	North American OSB production capacity by 15%. Once fully ramped up, this
	expansion will further strengthen Norbord's position as one of the largest OSB
	producers in the US South. In addition to the capital cost of $135 million, $8
	million of interest and $5 million of start-up costs have been capitalized since
	construction began in the second quarter of 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Capital investments in 2006,
	excluding the new Cordele OSB line, were $56 million, representing 60% of
	depreciation (2005 &#150; 87%). Approximately 55% of the $56 million was invested in
	projects designed to enhance profitability. In addition, $97 million was
	invested in the Cordele mill expansion project and $7 million of interest was
	capitalized bringing the total capital investment in 2006 to $160 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At year-end 2006, commitments to
	projects in progress totalled $16 million. Norbord's 2007 capital investments
	are expected to be $30 million, representing committed capital and essential
	maintenance only. Should market conditions warrant, this could be increased to
	$40 million, or approximately 40% of depreciation. The 2007 capital investments
	will be funded with cash on hand, cash generated from operations and, if
	necessary, drawdowns under the Company's committed bank lines.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX">
	The following table summarizes Norbord's capital
	investments:
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_15"></A>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="34%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	(US $ millions)
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="6%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="6%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	2006
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="6%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="6%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2005
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="6%">

<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION_15"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Management's
	Discussion and Analysis
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	22
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Capital investment was higher for 2006 and 2005 as compared to
	prior years as the Company expanded capacity at the Cordele mill, accelerated
	capital projects focused on energy reduction and production enhancement and
	prioritized projects designed to meet MACT (Maximum Achievable Control
	Technology) requirements (see Risks and Uncertainties &#150; Environmental
	Matters).
</P>
<B>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_16"></A>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Provision for Non-Core Operation
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In December 2006, the Company recorded a provision relating to
	the indefinite closure of the I-joist mill in Juniper, New Brunswick, following
	notification from the mill's major customer that its contract would not be
	renewed. The provision of $13 million ($0.06 per share) consisted of asset
	writedowns of $12 million and severances and other costs of $1 million. Earnings
	and balance sheet information relating to these assets follows:
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>

	&nbsp;

	2006
</B>

<FONT SIZE=2>
<P>
	Notwithstanding the writedown taken, efforts to find replacement customers
	for the mill's product continue.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Capitalization
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Dividends
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Dividends to common shareholders totalled $178 million in 2006
	and $166 million in 2005 including the payment of a CAD $1.00 per share special
	dividend in each of the third quarter of 2006 and the second quarter of 2005. In
	addition to the special dividends, the Company paid a regular dividend of CAD
	$0.40 in both 2006 and 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX">
	Preferred share dividends totalled $1 million in
	2005. All of the outstanding preferred shares were redeemed in the second
	quarter of 2005 (see Capitalization &#150; Preferred Share Redemption).
</P>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Purchase of Common Shares
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, the Company purchased and cancelled 2.7 million common
	shares at a cost of $29 million under a share repurchase program that expired on
	November 1, 2006. The share repurchase program was not renewed. In 2005, 5.7
	million shares were purchased and cancelled at a cost of $54 million.
</P>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Preferred Share Redemption
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the second quarter of 2005, the Company redeemed all of
	the outstanding Class A Series I preferred shares at par (CAD $60 million). On
	redemption, a foreign exchange loss of $9 million was recorded as a charge to
	equity. This one-time charge did not impact earnings. However, the charge
	reduced earnings per share by $0.06 as it was included in the determination of
	earnings available to common shareholders, the numerator in the earnings per
	share calculation. Following the redemption, the Company's issued equity is
	comprised solely of common shares. The redemption eliminated the Company's
	financial obligation with the highest after-tax cost.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>
<B>
	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT SIZE=5>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>

<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_17"></A>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Repurchase of Long-term Debt
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2005, the Company repurchased and cancelled $10 million of
	the 7
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/4
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	% debentures due 2012
	and unwound a corresponding amount of interest rate swaps. The premium paid on
	repurchase was offset by the recognition of gains on the interest rate
	swaps.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Selected Quarterly Information
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
</FONT>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The price of North American OSB is the primary factor affecting
	the comparability of Norbord's results over the past eight quarters.
	Fluctuations in earnings during that time mirror fluctuations in the price of
	OSB in North America. The Company estimates the annualized impact of a $10 per
	Msf (
<SUP>
	7
</SUP>
<FONT SIZE=1>
	/16
</FONT>
	-inch basis) change in the North
	American OSB price on EBITDA in 2006 was approximately $30 million or
	approximately $0.14 per share. Regional pricing variations, particularly in the
	US South, make the North Central benchmark price a useful, albeit imperfect,
	proxy for overall North American OSB pricing. Further, the pricing lag effect of
	maintaining an order file, premiums obtained on value added products, and volume
	and trade discounts cause realized prices to differ from the benchmark.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord has a relatively low exposure
	to the Canadian dollar due to a comparatively small manufacturing base in
	Canada, comprising 13% of its panel production capacity. The Company estimates
	the unfavourable impact of a US one-cent increase in the Canadian dollar to
	negatively impact annual earnings by approximately $1 million or less than $0.01
	per share.
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON>

	Some of the statements included in this MD&amp;A
	constitute forward-looking statements that are based on various
	assumptions and are subject to various risks.
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

	See the cautionary
	statement contained in the Forward-Looking Statements
	section.
</B>
</FONT>
