<EFX_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT>
<A NAME="FIS_NOTES_TO_FINANCIAL_STATEMENT"></A>
<A NAME="eolPage50"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Notes to the
	Consolidated Financial Statements
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL
	REPORT
<BR>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" WIDTH="16%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	43
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=5>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
	(in millions of US dollars, except per share
	information)
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In these notes "Norbord" means Norbord Inc. and all of its
	consolidated subsidiaries and affiliates, and "Company" means Norbord Inc. as a
	separate corporation, unless the context implies otherwise.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 1. Accounting Policies
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Basis of Presentation
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of
	the Company and all of its subsidiaries.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Use of Estimates
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
	Canadian generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) requires management to
	make estimates that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the
	disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities, and the reported revenues and
	expenses during a period. Actual results could differ from those
	estimates.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash and Cash Equivalents
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Cash and cash equivalents consist of demand deposits and
	investment grade money market securities and bank term deposits with a maturity
	of three months or less from the date of purchase. Cash and cash equivalents are
	recorded at cost, which approximates market value.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Inventories
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Inventories of raw materials and operating and maintenance
	supplies are valued at the lower of cost and replacement cost, with cost
	determined on an average cost basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Inventories of finished goods are
	valued at the lower of cost and net realizable value, with cost determined on an
	average cost basis. Cost includes direct material, direct labour and an
	allocation of overhead.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Property, Plant and Equipment
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost and are
	depreciated on a straight-line basis. The rates of depreciation are intended to
	fully depreciate the assets over the following periods which approximate their
	useful lives:
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="60%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="67%" BGCOLOR=#E6EACC>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Buildings
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="33%" BGCOLOR=#E6EACC>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	20 to 40 years
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="67%">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Production
	equipment
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="33%">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	10 to 15
	years
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Interest is capitalized on major capital projects during
	construction. Costs, net of revenues, incurred during the start-up period of
	major capital projects are deferred as other assets and amortized over the early
	productive life of the project.
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage51"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Notes to the
	Consolidated Financial Statements
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
<TR>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	44
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</FONT>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Employee Future Benefits
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord sponsors various defined benefit and defined
	contribution pension plans, which cover substantially all employees and are
	funded in accordance with applicable plan and regulatory requirements. The
	benefits under Norbord's defined benefit pension plans are generally based on an
	employee's length of service and the final five years' average salary, and the
	plans do not provide for indexation of benefit payments. Norbord also provides
	non-pension post-retirement benefits consisting of health care benefits to
	eligible retirees of certain former businesses, which are funded on a
	pay-as-you-go basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The measurement date for all defined
	benefit plans is December 31. The obligations associated with Norbord's defined
	benefit plans are actuarially valued using the projected unit credit method pro
	rated on services, management's best estimate assumptions for expected
	investment performance, salary escalation and health care cost trend rates, and
	a current market discount rate. For the purpose of calculating the expected
	return on plan assets, those assets are measured at fair value. Prior service
	costs related to plan amendments and transitional assets are amortized on a
	straight-line basis over the estimated average remaining service lives (EARSL)
	of the employee groups. The net actuarial gains or losses in excess of 10% of
	the greater of the accrued benefit obligation and the fair value of plan assets
	are amortized on a straight-line basis over EARSL.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Revenue Recognition
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Net sales are recognized when the risks and rewards of
	ownership pass to the purchaser. This is generally when goods are shipped. Sales
	are recorded net of third party transportation and discounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Sales are governed by contract or by
	standard industry terms. Revenue is not recognized prior to the completion of
	those terms. The majority of product is shipped via third-party transport on a
	freight-on-board shipping basis. In all cases, product is subject to quality
	testing by the Company to ensure it meets applicable standards prior to
	shipment.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Stock Options
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company accounts for stock options using the fair value
	method. Under the fair value method, compensation expense for options is
	measured at the grant date using the Black-Scholes option pricing model and
	recognized in earnings on a straight-line basis over the vesting period.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Income Taxes
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company uses the liability method of accounting for income
	taxes. Accordingly, future tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the
	future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial
	statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their
	respective tax bases. Future tax assets and liabilities are measured using
	enacted or substantively enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income
	in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered
	or settled. In addition, the effect on future tax assets and liabilities of a
	change in tax rates is recognized in income in the year that includes the
	enactment or substantive enactment date.
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage52"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Notes to the
	Consolidated Financial Statements
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL
	REPORT
<BR>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" WIDTH="16%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	45
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Translation of Foreign Currencies
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The accounts of subsidiaries having a functional currency other
	than the US dollar are translated using the current rate method. Gains or losses
	on translation are deferred and shown as a separate item in shareholders'
	equity. Gains or losses on foreign currency-denominated balances and
	transactions that are designated as hedges of investments in these subsidiaries
	are reported in the same manner as translation adjustments.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Monetary assets and liabilities
	denominated in currencies other than an entity's functional currency are
	translated at the rate of exchange prevailing at year-end. Gains or losses on
	translation of these items are included in the consolidated statement of
	earnings. Gains or losses on transactions that hedge these items are also
	included in the consolidated statement of earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Gains or losses on transactions that
	serve to hedge future foreign currency-denominated cash flows are recognized at
	their settlement dates and are reported in the same manner as the cash flows
	being hedged.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Financial Instruments
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company utilizes derivative financial instruments solely to
	manage its foreign currency, interest rate, and commodity price exposures in the
	ordinary course of business. Derivatives are not used for trading or speculative
	purposes. All hedging relationships, risk management objectives, and hedging
	strategies are formally documented and periodically assessed to ensure the
	changes in the value of these derivatives are highly effective in offsetting
	changes in the fair values, net investment or cash flows of the hedged
	exposures. Accordingly, all gains and losses (realized and unrealized, as
	applicable) on such derivatives are recognized in the same manner as gains and
	losses on the underlying exposure being hedged. Any resulting carrying amounts
	are included in other assets if there is an unrealized gain on the derivative or
	other liabilities if there is an unrealized loss on the derivative.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The carrying value of financial
	instruments approximates fair value, except where disclosed in these notes. Fair
	values disclosed are determined using actual quoted market prices or, if not
	available, indicative prices based on similar publicly traded instruments. The
	fair value of derivative financial instruments reflects the estimated amount
	that the Company would have paid or received if forced to settle all outstanding
	contracts at year-end. This fair value represents a point-in-time estimate that
	may not be relevant in predicting the Company's future earnings or cash
	flows.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is exposed to credit risk
	in the event of non-performance by its derivatives counterparties. However, the
	Company's Board-approved financial policies require that derivative transactions
	be executed only with approved highly rated counterparties under master netting
	agreements; therefore, the Company does not anticipate any
	non-performance.
</P>
<B>

<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Maturities of long-term debt at December 31, 2006 were: 2007 &#150;
	nil; 2008 &#150; $200; 2009 &#150; nil; 2010 &#150; $40; 2011 &#150; nil; and subsequent &#150; $240.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company has committed unsecured
	revolving bank lines of $200 that mature in 2010, bear interest at money market
	rates plus a margin that varies with the Company's credit rating, and contain
	certain financial covenants which the Company must comply with on a quarterly
	basis. At December 31, 2006, $44 of these lines were utilized; $40 drawn as cash
	and $4 drawn for letters of credit. The balance of $156 is available to support
	short-term liquidity requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At December 31, 2006, the Company had
	$365 (2005 &#150; $365) of interest rate swaps outstanding. The terms of these swaps
	correspond to the terms of the underlying debentures. In 2005, the Company
	repurchased and cancelled $10 of the 7
<SUP>
	1
</SUP>
	/
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 7PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	4
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	% debentures due 2012 and unwound a corresponding
	amount of interest rate swaps. The premium paid on repurchase was offset by the
	recognition of gains on the interest rate swaps.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The effective interest rate on the
	Company's debt-related obligations including the impact of the interest rate
	swaps was 7.7% at December 31, 2006 (2005 &#150; 7.2%). The aggregate fair value of
	the Company's debt was $493, consisting of debt of $494 and gains on interest
	rate swaps of $1.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Interest expense on long-term debt
	for the year, including the impact of interest rate swaps, was $29 (2005 &#150; $30).
	Total interest paid during the year was $42 (2005 &#150; $36).
</P>
<B>

	Repurchase
	of common shares

<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2005, the Company redeemed all of the outstanding Class A
	series I preferred shares at par value (CAD $60). On redemption, a foreign
	exchange loss of $9 was recorded as a charge to retained earnings.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company declared a special
	dividend of CAD $1.00 per common share which was paid on July 14, 2006. In 2005,
	the Company declared a special dividend of CAD $1.00 per common share which was
	paid on May 20, 2005.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Under the Company's stock option
	plan, the Board of Directors of the Company may issue stock options to certain
	directors and employees of the Company. These options vest over a five-year
	period and expire 10 years from the date of issue. Included in cost of sales is
	$1 (2005 &#150; $1) related to these options. During the year, the exercise price on
	all outstanding options was decreased by CAD $1.00 (2005 &#150; CAD $1.00) to reflect
	the payment of the special dividend.
</P>
</FONT>

<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_34"></A>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 7. Earnings per Common Share
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P>
	Earnings per common share were calculated as follows:

<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Stock options issued under the Company's stock option plan
	(note 6) were included in the calculation of diluted number of common shares to
	the extent the exercise price of those options was less than the average market
	price of the Company's common shares during the year.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 8. Provision for Non-Core
	Operation
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In December 2006, the Company recorded a provision relating to
	the indefinite closure of an I-joist mill in Juniper, New Brunswick following
	notification from the mill's major customer that its contract would not be
	renewed. The provision of $13 consisted of asset writedowns of $12 and the
	accrual of severances and other costs of $1.
</P>
<B>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_35"></A>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 9. Income Tax
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Future income taxes reflect the net tax effects of temporary
	differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities in the
	financial statements and the amounts used for income tax purposes.
</P>

	following:

<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Note 11. Employee Benefit Plans Pension Plans
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord has a number of pension plans in which participation is
	available to substantially all employees. Norbord's obligations under its
	defined benefit pension plans are determined periodically through the
	preparation of actuarial valuations, which are generally required every three
	years. The most recent actuarial valuation was conducted as of December 31,
	2005. The date of the next required valuation is December 31, 2008, and Norbord
	may choose to perform an actuarial valuation at an earlier date. Information
	about these plans is as follows:
</P>
</FONT>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Operating costs include $7 (2005 &#150; $7) related to contributions
	to Norbord's defined contribution pension plans.
</P>
<B>
<P>
	Post-Retirement Benefit Plans
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord funds health care benefits costs on a pay-as-you-go
	basis. Norbord's obligations under its post-retirement benefit plan are
	determined periodically through actuarial valuations. At December 31, 2006, the
	accrued benefit obligation related to this plan was $3 (2005 &#150; $4) and the net
	accrued liability was $2 (2005 &#150; $2). During the year, nil (2005 &#150; nil) was
	included in operating costs related to this plan.
</P>
<B>
<P>
	Post-Employment Benefits
</P>
</B>
<P>
	Operating costs include $2 (2005 &#150; $2) related to severance payments.
</P>
<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 12. Commitments &amp; Contingencies
</FONT>
</P>
<P>
	Softwood Lumber Duties
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, the Company received $7 in refunded duties and
	interest pursuant to the Canada-US Softwood Lumber Agreement which is included
	in earnings before interest, income tax, depreciation and provision for non-core
	operation in the consolidated statement of earnings. The refund relates to
	duties paid by two sawmills sold in October 2003.
</P>
</FONT>

<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Foreign Exchange Hedges
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At year-end, the Company had outstanding forward foreign
	exchange contracts of &#163;5 (2005 &#150; &#163;9) and
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#128;
</FONT>
	59 (2005
	&#150;
</FONT>
<FONT LANG=JA FACE=NWUMPG+TIMES SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#128;
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	64) and cross-currency swaps of
	&#163;125 (2005 &#150; &#163;125), which were designated as hedges against its net investments
	in Europe. In 2006, the Company realized a loss of $13 (2005 &#150; gain of $12) on
	its matured net investment hedges and, at year-end, the Company had an
	unrealized loss of $25 (2005 &#150; gain of $1) on its outstanding net investment
	hedges. These realized and unrealized losses were offset by realized and
	unrealized gains on the net investments being hedged.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In addition, at year-end, the Company
	had outstanding forward foreign exchange contracts of CAD $9 (2005 &#150; CAD $42),
	which were designated as a hedge against certain Canadian dollar-denominated
	monetary liabilities. In 2006, the Company realized a loss of $1 (2005 &#150; gain of
	$1) on its matured monetary liability hedges and, at year-end, the Company had
	an unrealized gain of nil (2005 &#150; nil) on these outstanding hedges. These
	realized and unrealized gains were offset by realized and unrealized losses on
	the monetary liabilities being hedged.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company has entered into various
	commitments for capital expenditures and services in connection with capital
	investment projects. At year-end, the Company had outstanding forward foreign
	exchange contracts of
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#128;
</FONT>
	4 (2005 &#150;
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#128;
</FONT>
	9)
	which were designated as hedges against certain of these commitments. No gains
	or losses were realized in 2006. At year-end the Company had an unrealized gain
	of nil on the outstanding hedges. Realized and unrealized losses, if any, are
	offset by realized and unrealized gains on the purchase commitments being
	hedged.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Guarantee of Certain Obligations of Fraser Papers
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord continues to guarantee certain obligations under
	operating lease commitments of Fraser Papers, which was distributed to common
	shareholders in 2004. The maximum potential amount of future payments that
	Norbord could be required to make under these obligations is estimated to be $7.
	No amounts have been recorded in the consolidated balance sheet with respect to
	these guarantees. As security for these ongoing financial commitments to Fraser
	Papers, Norbord has the right, at any time, to require Fraser Papers to provide
	a fixed first-charge security interest over Fraser Papers' manufacturing
	facilities. In 2006, the fee for providing these guarantees was less than
	$1.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Class Action Lawsuit
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord and eight other North American OSB producers have been
	named as defendants in several lawsuits filed in the United States District
	Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The lawsuits allege that these
	nine North American OSB producers violated United States and various state
	antitrust and other laws by allegedly agreeing to fix prices and reduce the
	supply of OSB from June 1, 2002 through the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The named plaintiffs seek to have the
	cases certified as class actions. One group of plaintiffs seeks to certify a
	class of persons and entities that purchased OSB in the United States directly
	from any of the named North American OSB producers between June 1, 2002 and the
	present. Other plaintiffs seek to certify one or more classes of persons and
	entities that purchased OSB in various states and the District of Columbia
	indirectly between June 1, 2002 and the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company believes that the
	lawsuits are entirely without merit and intends to defend this matter
	vigorously.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PMOYRC+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<B>
<P>
	Other
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company received tax advice and a tax ruling on certain tax
	matters related to the distribution of Fraser Papers. There can be no assurance
	that tax authorities will not challenge various tax filing positions
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	taken by the Company. Such a challenge could
	result in an income tax and/or a withholding tax liability. In addition to the
	foregoing, the Company is subject to various additional uncertainties concerning
	the interpretation and application of tax laws in operating jurisdictions that
	could affect the Company's cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>

<B>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 13. Related Party Transactions
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company's major shareholder has various interests over
	which it has control or otherwise has significant influence (a "related company"
	or collectively "related companies").
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006 and 2005, the Company
	provided certain administrative services to a related company which were charged
	on a cost recovery basis. In addition, the Company periodically engages the
	services of related companies for various financial, real estate and other
	business advisory services.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, the fees for these services
	were less than $1 and were charged at market rates. In 2006, the Company
	received a payment of $3 from a related company as final consideration pursuant
	to a 1999 Asset Purchase Agreement. The payment was contingent on the completion
	of an expansion project. In addition, Norbord paid $1 to this related company
	for certain costs for which Norbord provided an indemnity under the same 1999
	Asset Purchase Agreement. Total future costs related to this indemnification are
	estimated at $1 and are included in other liabilities in the consolidated
	balance sheet.
</P>
<B>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_42"></A>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Note 14. Geographic Segments
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company has a single reportable segment. The Company
	operates principally in North America and Europe. Net sales by geographic
	segment are determined based on the origin of shipment and therefore include
	export sales.
</P>

<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P>
	Principal Operating Interests
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Information regarding Norbord&#146;s principal operating interests
	is set forth in the following table. The estimated annual production capacity is
	based on normal operating rates and normal production mixes under current market
	conditions, taking into account known constraints, such as permit restrictions.
	Market conditions, fluctuations in raw material availability, mechanical
	interruptions and the nature of current orders may cause actual production rates
	and mixes to vary significantly from the estimated production rates and mixes
	used to derive the estimated annual capacities shown.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>

	Annual Capacity

	&nbsp;

	during 2006.

<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=5>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Message to Shareholders
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s environment, health and safety activities are based
	on two fundamentally important beliefs: First we must provide a safe,
	injury-free workplace. Second, the management of environmental risk is an
	integral part of our business planning and success.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We apply these beliefs 24 hours a
	day, 365 days a year. It&#146;s a full-time, constant commitment and one that we are
	always working to improve upon.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Health and Safety Performance
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2006 our safety performance improved. But we are still
	short of the world class performance we know we can achieve. Most tragically, a
	fatal incident occurred at our Joanna, South Carolina OSB mill in November 2006
	reinforcing the need for vigilance and continued learning throughout the
	organization.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On a positive note, we made several achievements:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We improved our OSHA recordable rate by more than 20% over
	2005.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We polled every employee to identify barriers to eliminating
	injuries in the workplace and to help define a strategy for further
	improvement.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Nacogdoches, Texas mill set a Norbord record with a 2006
	OSHA recordable rate of zero &#150; making it one of the safest OSB mills in the
	world. In addition, mills in Huguley, Alabama, Nacogdoches and Jefferson,
	Texas each celebrated more than one million hours worked without a lost time
	injury.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Management of Environmental Risk Shows Real
	Improvement
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Core to our business and capital planning is the identification
	of risks and opportunities. Understanding these opportunities is essential to
	reducing the environmental impact of our operations while maintaining efficient
	manufacturing systems.
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We continue to use more residual wood for energy production.
	We have invested $55 million to reduce dependence on fossil fuel and have
	reduced natural gas consumption and greenhouse gas emissions by30%.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We moved quickly toward compliance with new US environmental
	regulations &#150; investing $29 million in air emission controls and reducing
	emissions from our US plants by more than 1,000 metric tons per year.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We achieved a 98% compliance rate as measured against our own
	leading indicators of environmental performance.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In this report we discuss the environment, health and safety
	risks that we feel have the greatest potential to impact the long-term
	sustainability of our business. For a more detailed review of our performance I
	invite you to explore the Compendium of Environment, Health and Safety Data
	available on our web site (www.norbord.com).
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<IMG HEIGHT=39 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_NBDF404.GIF" WIDTH=159 BORDER=0>
<BR>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
	J. Barrie Shineton
<BR>
	President and Chief Executive Officer
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 24PT" FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Environment Policy
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Norbord recognizes that our environment is
	fundamental to our existence, and that our businesses and the communities where
	we operate depend on its health. We strive for excellence, leadership,
	sustainability and competitive advantage &#150; with integrity &#150; through continual
	improvement in our environmental performance and management of forest land. For
	Norbord, sustainable development means creating economic growth and caring for
	society and the environment, while taking into account the needs of future
	generations.
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord will integrate environmental protection into our
	business processes and decisions. Our belief in sustainable development means we
	are committed to:
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Full Compliance:
</B>
	Comply fully with all applicable
	environmental legislation and regulations that affect our activities.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Forest Management:
</B>
	Manage forest resources in a manner
	consistent with the principles of sustainable forestry, this policy and
	applicable legislation.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Minimization of Environmental Impact:
</B>
	Improve our
	environmental performance as the expectations of society change. We shall do
	this by using forest, energy and other resources with increasing efficiency, and
	by reducing all forms of waste.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Risk Management:
</B>
	Continually identify, evaluate and control
	the environmental risks associated with our operations. We shall have procedures
	in place to prevent and respond to emergencies.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Environmental Management Systems:
</B>
	Implement systematic
	environmental management which supports this policy at every operation. We shall
	assign appropriate human and financial resources. Every year we shall establish
	measurable objectives and targets for environmental management and performance
	improvement.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Innovation:
</B>
	Support pollution prevention and
	environmental research, and implement findings consistent with this
	policy.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Performance Evaluation:
</B>
	Evaluate the environmental
	performance of our operations and personnel, and recognize achievements that
	support this policy. We shall provide our employees with information and
	training for them to fully integrate this policy into their responsibilities at
	work.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Communication with Stakeholders:
</B>
	Engage in constructive
	dialogue with the communities in which we operate and other key stakeholders,
	taking their needs into account when we make our decisions.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Open Government Relations:
</B>
	Work constructively with
	governments and regulators on the establishment of scientifically and
	economically sound requirements for our operations.
</P>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Audits:
</B>
	Conduct environmental audits at all our operations
	at a frequency appropriate to their risks.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
	Reports:
</B>
	Report regularly on our environmental
	performance to the management of the Corporation, the Board of Directors, our
	shareholders, employees and the communities in which we operate.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord requires its operations to develop policies, systems,
	organizations, and competencies, and to embrace an environmental commitment
	consistent with these principles. Norbord requires all employees to take
	responsibility for environmental protection in their jobs.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>

<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P>
	Health and Safety Policy
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P>
	We are committed to safeguarding the health and well-being of our employees,
	contractors and visitors by creating and maintaining a safe working
	environment.
</P>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Beliefs
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<UL>
<LI>
	All injuries and occupational illnesses are preventable.
<LI>
	Health and safety is a top priority and an integral part of our business
	and decision-making.
<LI>
	Management is ultimately responsible for workplace health and safety.
<LI>
	Safe operating practices are a shared responsibility among management,
	employees, contractors and visitors.
<LI>
	Employees and contractors are accountable for their safety and that of
	fellow workers.
<LI>
	Working safely is a condition of employment.
<LI>
	Sharing best practices improves performance.
</LI>
</UL>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Practices
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<UL>
<LI>
	Design safe facilities.
<LI>
	Continually review and improve processes and procedures.
<LI>
	Identify hazards and assess risks.
<LI>
	Develop, implement and enforce safe work practices.
<LI>
	Ensure all facilities comply with applicable laws and regulations.
<LI>
	Provide employees with information and training to work safely.
<LI>
	Require employees and contractors to execute their work in accordance with
	legislative requirements and Norbord policy.
<LI>
	Establish and monitor health and safety objectives.
<LI>
	Take action to prevent recurrence of incidents.
<LI>
	Implement health and safety management systems to continually improve
	performance.
<LI>
	Conduct health and safety audits.
<LI>
	Report health and safety performance to senior management, the Board of
	Directors, shareholders, employees and the public.
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

	Environment,
	Health and Safety Report

<TR>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=3>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	A
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	NNUAL REPORT

</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=UGIYES+ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
	2006

</FONT>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">

<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	66
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;

</TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Safety
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Every Norbord employee has the right to work in a safe
	workplace where training, elimination of risk and individual and collective
	responsibilities for safety are central to management practices. In 2006 we made
	progress toward our goal of an injury-free workplace. Our 2006 OSHA recordable
	injury rate was 20% better than 2005 and 17% below our five-year average.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At the beginning of the year we
	polled every employee to identify the barriers to improved performance. More
	than 85% of employees participated, helping to define a strategy for improvement
	that will strengthen communication, increase opportunities for employee
	participation in safety activities, continually evaluate and reduce risk, and
	ensure that Norbord&#146;s equipment and practices are in keeping with world class
	safety standards.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_47"></A>

	Health and Safety
	Data

	2006

</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: #949B51 2PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH=128>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 2PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH=128>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P>
	(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Per 200,000 hours
	worked.
<BR>
	(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Genk mill acquired in 2004; figures
	included starting in 2005.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While progress has been made, we have yet to achieve world
	class performance. In November a process technician with seven years experience
	in the Joanna mill was performing a routine cleaning task when he was fatally
	injured. Internal and outside expertise was engaged to investigate the incident.
	We quickly communicated findings throughout the Company and have put in place
	corrective actions to respond to any issues that were identified.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On a more positive note, sustained
	vigilance and a motivated workforce have contributed to a 55% improvement in
	safety performance at the Genk operation. In addition, mills in Huguley,
	Nacogdoches and Jefferson have each surpassed one million hours worked without a
	lost time injury. The Nacogdoches mill recorded a perfect safety record during
	the year with zero recordable injuries, making it one of the safest OSB mills in
	the world.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<B>
<P>
	Managing Environmental Risks
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While industrial manufacturing activities do pose inherent
	risks, Norbord&#146;s manufacturing processes and the regulatory requirements imposed
	on our operations ensure that there are no significant risks to the environment
	or the communities in which we operate. For example:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
	The majority of the wood fibre used in our products is from short
	rotation, sustainably managed forests or recycled sources.
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s manufacturing process uses residual wood fuel to
	provide heat and in some cases electrical energy consumed in manufacturing.
	More than 70% of the energy needed to make OSB is derived from residual wood
	fuel.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Chemical use in the panelboard manufacturing process is
	restricted to the use of relatively small quantities of phenol and urea
	formaldehyde based and polymeric methylene diphenyl diisocyanate (PMDI) based
	resins. The use of these resins is tightly controlled and monitored at all
	times to safeguard employees, customers and the surrounding community from
	exposure.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage73"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health
	and Safety Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="13%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	67
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="15%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Air emissions from the
	manufacturing process primarily consist of:
</FONT>
</P>
<LI>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	water vapour, volatile organic compounds (VOCs), fine wood particulates
	and natural wood-based materials such as terpenes, alcohols, acetaldehyde and
	acrolein that are released when wood is heated for drying;
</P>
<LI>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	fine particulate wood ash, nitrogen
	oxides, carbon monoxide and trace amounts of manganese from the combustion of
	wood and natural gas for the production of heat and electrical energy; and
</P>
<LI>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	formaldehyde and methanol from both
	the wood drying and panel pressing processes.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The panelboard manufacturing process uses and discharges very
	little water, most of which is a byproduct of steam production, wood chip
	washing, air emission scrubbing systems and non-industrial sewage. All process
	discharges are treated on-site using appropriate water treatment systems or
	are sent to municipal effluent treatment systems.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Wood ash, wood debris contaminated with soil and rocks and
	general trash are the primary wastes produced. Wherever possible, materials
	are reused or recycled including extensive use of wood ash as an approved
	agricultural supplement.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord generates in total less than 2,000 metric tons of
	hazardous waste per year, which is properly characterized and disposed of
	under tight regulatory standards. Most of this hazardous waste consists of
	general cleaning products, paints, batteries and waste resins.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All production processes and
	emissions are subject to regulation and permit requirements imposed by
	jurisdictional government agencies. In the United States, strict environmental
	regulations are set federally and enforced through detailed state-issued
	permits. In Canada, provincial regulations require certificates of authorization
	defining the requirements of operation.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=RIGHT>
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;And in Europe, federal, regional and local government
	bodies work together to develop detailed integrated operating permits for each
	plant. Compliance with these permits requires internal monitoring, routine
	reporting and annual government inspections.
</P>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=215 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT2.GIF" WIDTH=331 BORDER=0>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Nonetheless, continual assessment and investment in risk
	reduction is integrated into Norbord&#146;s business planning process. While risks
	vary between regions, sites and by specific manufacturing process, there are
	four general categories of environmental risk that play an important part in
	Norbord&#146;s success in the near and long term:
</P>
</FONT>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Energy security and the management of greenhouse gas emissions.
</FONT>
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	New and proposed government regulations to limit
	air emissions.
</FONT>
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Management and control of formaldehyde as a
	by-product of the manufacturing process, as a contaminant in our workplaces
	and as a component in our products.
</FONT>
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
	Environmentally sound forestry practices and the sustainability
	of our fibre resources.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord assesses where opportunities exist for reducing all
	existing and potential risks, gives careful consideration to risk reduction in
	the deployment of capital and measures progress regularly.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health and Safety
	Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	68
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Energy Use and Greenhouse
	Gases
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, Norbord reduced dependence on fossil fuels, increased
	overall energy efficiency and subsequently reduced the emission of greenhouse
	gases. These measures, while obviously beneficial to the environment, were also
	an effective means of cost control, further enhancing Norbord&#146;s industry-leading
	cost position.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=208 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT3.GIF" WIDTH=650 BORDER=0>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All Norbord operations in the UK have entered into Kyoto
	climate change energy efficiency agreements which have, to-date, resulted in
	savings of more than &#163;10 million through tax and energy efficiency cost savings.
	A "cap and trade" carbon trading scheme, rolled out across Europe in 2005, will
	create further potential for financial gains for Norbord&#146;s Genk and Cowie
	mills.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<DIR>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=200 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT4.GIF" WIDTH=605 BORDER=0>
</P>
</DIR>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While similar Kyoto-driven initiatives have been slower to
	develop in North America, Norbord has nonetheless aggressively pursued energy
	efficiency improvements. Norbord reduced natural gas usage by 30% in 2006 over
	2005. Most of these gains are the result of a $30 million investment in the
	Jefferson heat energy system completed in late 2005. In 2006, Norbord invested
	more than $5 million in energy efficiency projects including:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
	Installation of a 10MW wood-fired energy system in Cowie that will
	significantly reduce overall natural gas use when it is fully ramped
	up.
</FONT>
</LI>
</UL>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage75"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%" HEIGHT=21>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health
	and Safety Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2 HEIGHT=21>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%" HEIGHT=15>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2 HEIGHT=15>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%" HEIGHT=24>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2 HEIGHT=24>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%" HEIGHT=37>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="13%" HEIGHT=38>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	69
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="15%" HEIGHT=37>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At Cordele, conversion of a regenerative thermal oxidizer
	(RTO) to a regenerative catalytic oxidizer (RCO) that is already reducing
	natural gas use for press air emission control by approximately one-third and
	saving over $700,000 per year.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Installation of new process controls for the Deposit
	wood-fired boiler which will increase reliability and reduce dependence on the
	gas-fired back-up boiler.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The full operational and financial benefits of these projects
	will be reflected in 2007. However, Norbord is moving forward on additional
	initiatives that will drive another 10% reduction in fossil fuel use. These
	projects include:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A $20 million investment in residual wood-fired heat energy
	systems for OSB dryers in Genk and Nacogdoches. After completion, all of
	Norbord&#146;s OSB process heat energy needs will be met using residual wood fuel.
</P>
<LI>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Installation of improved ash handling systems in Huguley and
	Joanna to increase the efficiency of their boilers.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Many of these projects have required significant capital
	investment but Norbord has also been successful with an incremental approach to
	energy efficiency. For example, over the last five years, the Inverness,
	Scotland mill has reduced the amount of natural gas and electricity needed to
	make each unit of product by more than 50%. This was achieved without
	significant capital investment by involving employees, setting stretch targets
	and using available low-cost technology.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We will continue to reduce our
	overall dependence on fossil fuels and decrease greenhouse gas emissions.
	However, environmental regulations in the United States continue to increase the
	need for air emission control equipment that depends on natural gas. Today 18%
	of our annual natural gas use goes towards operating air emission control
	equipment &#150; RTOs and RCOs. This is enough energy to run one of our plants for
	six months.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<I>
<P>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Air Emissions and Regulatory
	Compliance
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, Norbord continued to deliberately invest in early
	compliance with a changing regulatory landscape, specifically with respect to
	two Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) standards that impact most of
	Norbord&#146;s US operations. To date, the Company has spent $29 million on improved
	air emission control equipment to meet these standards. All of the affected US
	operations have completed the necessary assessments and submitted permit
	applications to comply with the Boiler MACT standards by the September 2007
	compliance deadline. No additional capital will be required to meet the new
	boiler standards.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=186 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT5.GIF" WIDTH=636 BORDER=0>
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage76"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health and Safety
	Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	70
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Compliance with the more complex and more rigorous Plywood and
	Composite Wood Products (PCWP) MACT is not required until October 2008. Mills in
	Joanna, Deposit, Jefferson and Nacogdoches are currently in compliance with all
	MACT requirements. Additional capital investment to comply with PCWP MACT is not
	expected to exceed $8 million.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s actions to comply with
	these regulations ahead of the compliance deadline have significantly reduced
	emissions while enhancing operational flexibility. This has allowed Norbord&#146;s
	mills to increase production without restrictive production caps. In 2006,
	Norbord made significant progress in reducing US air emissions in every
	category. Annual emissions of criteria air pollutants in the US (including VOC,
	particulate, NOx and CO) were reduced by more than 1,000 metric tons last year,
	a reduction of 20% over 2004.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord manages compliance by
	recording any deviation from a permit-required monitoring parameter. Most of
	these deviations are only minutes in duration and do not result in permit
	violations or harmful releases to the environment. Continuous monitoring allows
	us to react to emission control equipment malfunctions before there is a risk to
	the environment.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>

</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX; TEXT-INDENT: -30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<SUP>
	(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Of the 529 deviations reported in 2006, 70% were from
	Nacogdoches where new air emission control equipment and associated permit
	requirements have required operators to adjust to new
	monitoring&nbsp;procedures. The new equipment is functioning well and has
	accounted for a 600 metric ton per year reduction in VOC and formaldehyde
	emissions. The mill is in compliance with all permit emission limits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX; TEXT-INDENT: -30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(2)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Genk mill
	acquired in 2004; figures included starting in 2005.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX; TEXT-INDENT: -30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(3)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</SUP>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=RMVSFK+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	2006 environmental capital investment includes approximately $15 million
	for environmental equipment for the expansion of the Cordele OSB
	mill.
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Additional permit requirements and increasingly sophisticated
	abatement equipment mean that the number of parameters controlled by Norbord
	operators is always increasing. In 2006, Norbord took over 26,000 compliance
	measurements. Of these, 529 did not meet our operating criteria accounting for
	an overall environmental compliance rate of 97.9%. Seventy percent of the
	deviations reported in 2006 are from the Nacogdoches mill where new air emission
	control equipment and associated permit requirements have required operators to
	adjust to new monitoring procedures. The new equipment is functioning well and
	has accounted for a 600 metric ton per year reduction in VOC and formaldehyde
	emissions.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51>
<I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Formaldehyde
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Formaldehyde exists naturally in wood, the human body and the
	atmosphere. It is present in very low concentrations in the adhesive used in our
	panel products and is released from wood in the drying process.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While formaldehyde emissions from OSB
	are similar to the emissions from natural wood, products are nonetheless tested
	to ensure that they comply with agreed standards for formaldehyde content and
	emissions. Standards for all our products are well below the levels associated
	with any observed health effects and Norbord works with industry associations
	and resin suppliers in North America and Europe to set more demanding product
	quality targets.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage77"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health
	and Safety Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="13%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	71
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="15%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Employee exposure to formaldehyde is
	assessed regularly and compared to our own rigid standards. In addition, we
	conduct periodic health evaluations to ensure that employees are not
	experiencing any adverse health effects.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Prior to the start-up of a new mill
	or a new production line, we develop models to predict formaldehyde emissions
	and ensure that local communities will not be at risk. Pollution control
	equipment prevents most of the formaldehyde from ever reaching the atmosphere.
	The small amount released is closely monitored and publicly reported to the
	regulators. Improved controls have reduced formaldehyde emissions by 20% since
	2002 or over 50 metric tons a year on a like-for-like basis.
</P>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=186 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT6.GIF" WIDTH=325 BORDER=0>
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Sustainable Wood Procurement
</FONT>
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord does not own forest land. Wood fibre is supplied
	through contracts with private or industrial landowners, other forest products
	companies with long-term leases on public lands or directly from public forest
	management agencies. In Quebec and Ontario, Norbord holds long-term licences
	that permit the annual harvesting of approximately 880,000 cubic metres of
	poplar and birch.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At all Norbord operations, wood is
	delivered to our mills under specific contracts with qualified, professional
	loggers. Norbord sets strict standards for wood quality and regularly monitors
	contractors to ensure they meet environmental standards.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	We continue to increase the use of
	recycled wood in the manufacture of particleboard and MDF. Substitution of
	virgin fibre with recycled fibre conserves natural forest and reduces the amount
	of waste going to landfill. In addition, recycled material is drier than wood
	chipped from trees; therefore, the amount of energy needed to prepare the fibre
	for pressing can be reduced. In 2006, Norbord used approximately 400,000 metric
	tons of post-consumer wood fibre &#150; material that was reclaimed after being used
	in crating, pallets, window and door frames and other building
	materials.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=179 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT7.GIF" WIDTH=321 BORDER=0>
</P>
<P>
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=PVFKAS+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord continues to support
	initiatives to monitor and certify the sustainability of forest management in
	our procurement areas. Third parties are engaged to certify that our wood
	procurement and forest management practices meet internationally recognized
	standards endorsed by the Sustainable Forestry Initiative&#174; (SFI), Forest
	Stewardship Council (FSC) or the International Organization for Standardization
	(ISO), depending on the location of the mill. Nine of Norbord&#146;s North American
	wood procurement operations are third-party certified to be in compliance with
	the SFI requirements and the Canadian forestry operations are also registered
	under the ISO 14001 Environmental Management System standard. The four European
	mills meet the FSC Chain of Custody standards. The Cochrane mill is third-party
	certified under all three systems.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Certification to these standards
	ensures that harvesting conforms to recognized best management practices
	including the protection of water quality and wildlife. Compliance also requires
	that sustainable forest practices are furthered through education, training and
	research.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage78"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Environment, Health and Safety
	Report
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	ANNUAL REPORT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;

</TD>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	2006
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>

<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
	72
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<FONT COLOR=#949B51>
	Environment, Health and Safety
	Audits
</FONT>
</P>
</B>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Since the early 1990s, Norbord has conducted internal
	environment, health and safety audits to track and improve performance across
	all operations. Each Norbord mill is audited at least once every three years by
	an experienced team. Corrective action plans are closely tracked and progress is
	reported on a quarterly basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2006, audits were completed at
	Nacogdoches, La Sarre, Guntown and Genk. Members of Norbord&#146;s senior management
	team participate in these audits. In addition, internal EH&amp;S auditors
	visited the Cordele expansion project twice to review contractor safety
	practices and to ensure a safe start-up.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The audit process covers a wide range
	of EH&amp;S risks. In 2006, Norbord introduced revised environmental compliance
	auditing tools and increased attention to environmental permit requirements. In
	2007, additional employees will be trained as auditors to expand the scope of
	expertise involved in the program. In addition to the ongoing review and
	assessment of known and potential EH&amp;S risks, emphasis will be placed on
	monitoring progress towards a safety culture that identifies and eliminates
	hazards and further involves employees in all aspects of the EH&amp;S
	process.
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 9PT" FACE=ACASLON COLOR=#949B51 SIZE=6>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>

	generated
	onsite through the production

	heat and
</FONT>

	Most contribute,

	or
	combustion of energy.

	pressure.

<P ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG HEIGHT=887 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SEVENT9.JPG" WIDTH=763 BORDER=0>
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-TOP-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-LEFT-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-BOTTOM-WIDTH: 0PX; BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE; BORDER-RIGHT-WIDTH: 0PX" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=1>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" WIDTH="10%">

</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE: 14PT" FACE=ACASLON>
<P>
	Letter to Shareholders
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	March 1, 2007
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Dear Shareholder,
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On behalf of the Board of Directors, I would like to invite you
	to attend common shareholders at The National Club, 303 Bay Street, Toronto,
	Ontario on Wednesday, April 25, 2007 at 10:30 a.m. local time.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The business to be considered at this Meeting is described in
	the accompanying Notice of Annual Meeting and Management Proxy Circular. It is
	important that you exercise your vote, either in person or by completing and
	sending in your proxy.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As always, you will have the opportunity at the Meeting to meet
	with the Directors and Management of the Corporation, who will be happy to
	answer your questions. If you are unable to attend the meeting in person, I
	invite you to log on to our web site at www.norbord.com and listen to our web
	cast.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	I would also take this opportunity to advise you of the passing
	of a very valued Board member and Chair of our Audit Committee, Mr. Don S.
	Wells, on August 21, 2006. Mr. Wells had been a Director of the Corporation and
	Chair of the Audit Committee since April 2003. His expertise and wisdom will be
	greatly missed.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Sincerely,
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG HEIGHT=73 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_PAGES82.GIF" WIDTH=174 BORDER=0>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Robert J. Harding
<BR>
	Chair
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="FRANKLIN GOTHIC" SIZE=3>
