</B>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=4>
<P>
<B>
	Appendix E&#150;Audit Committee&#150;Terms of Reference
</B>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<P>
	Role of Audit Committee
</P>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The role of the Audit Committee is to assist the Board in its
	oversight of the integrity of the financial and related information of the
	Corporation including its financial statements, the internal controls and
	procedures for financial reporting and the processes for monitoring compliance
	with legal and regulatory requirements and to review the independence,
	qualifications and performance of the external auditor of the Corporation.
	Management is responsible for establishing and maintaining those controls,
	procedures and processes and the Audit Committee is appointed by the Board to
	review and monitor them.
</P>
<I>
<P>
	Authority and Responsibilities
</P>
</I>
<P>
	In carrying out its role, the Audit Committee has the following authority and
	responsibilities:
</P>
<P>
	1. Financial information and reporting&#150;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	(a) to review and discuss with
	management and the external auditor, as appropriate:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(i) the annual
	audited financial statements and the interim financial statements including the
	accompanying Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 78PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(ii) earnings
	guidance and other releases containing information taken from the Corporation&#146;s
	financial statements prior to their release; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(b) to review the
	Corporation&#146;s financial reporting and accounting standards and principles and
	any proposed material changes to them or their application;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	2. Internal controls&#150;to review, with the chief financial
	officer ("CFO"), the external auditor and others, as appropriate, the
	Corporation&#146;s system of internal controls;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	3. External audit&#150;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(a) to recommend
	to the Board, for shareholder approval, the external auditor to examine the
	Corporation&#146;s accounts, controls and financial statements on the basis that the
	external auditor is accountable to the Board and the Audit Committee as
	representatives of the shareholders of the Corporation;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(b) to evaluate
	the audit services provided by the external auditor, pre-approve all audit fees
	and recommend to the Board, if necessary, the replacement of the external
	auditor;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(c) to
	pre-approve any non-audit services to be provided to the Corporation or its
	subsidiaries by the external auditor and the fees for those services;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(d) to obtain and
	review at least annually a written report by the external auditor setting out
	the auditor&#146;s internal quality control procedures, any material issues raised by
	the auditor&#146;s internal quality control reviews and the steps taken to resolve
	those issues; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(e) to review at
	least annually the relationships between the Corporation and the external
	auditor in order to establish the independence of the external auditor;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	4. Risk management&#150;to review and monitor the Corporation&#146;s
	major financial risks and risk management policies and the steps taken by
	management to mitigate those risks; and
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage136"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="73%">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Appendix
	E&#150;Audit Committee&#150;Terms of Reference
</FONT>
</P>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	MANAGEMENT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	PROXY CIRCULAR
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="28%" COLSPAN=2>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="73%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="13%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=5>
<B>
	51
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="15%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P>
	5. Compliance &#150;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to review the Corporation&#146;s financial
	reporting procedures and policies to ensure compliance with all legal and
	regulatory requirements and to investigate any non-adherence to those procedures
	and policies; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; to establish procedures for the receipt and
	treatment of any complaint regarding accounting, internal accounting controls or
	auditing matters including procedures for the confidential, anonymous
	submissions by employees of concerns regarding questionable accounting or
	auditing matters.
</P>
</FONT>
<I>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P>
	Composition and Procedures
</P>
</FONT>
</I>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Size&#150;The Audit Committee will consist
	of a minimum of three Directors. The members of the Committee are appointed by
	the Board upon the recommendation of the Corporate Governance and Nominating
	Committee and may be removed by the Board in its discretion.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Qualifications&#150;All members of the
	Committee must be "independent" within the meaning of sections 1.4 and 1.5 of
	Multilateral Instrument 52-110. All members of the Committee must be
	"financially literate", i.e., have the ability to read and understand a set of
	financial statements that present a breadth and level of complexity of
	accounting issues that are generally comparable to the breadth and complexity of
	the issues that can reasonably be expected to be raised by the financial
	statements of the Corporation. At least one member of the Committee should have
	"accounting or related financial expertise", i.e., the ability to analyze and
	interpret a full set of financial statements, including the attached notes, in
	accordance with Canadian generally accepted accounting principles.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX">
	3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
	Meetings&#150;The Committee will meet at least five times a year and a portion of
	each meeting will be held without the presence of management.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Review of Financial Statements&#150;The
	Committee will review the Corporation&#146;s annual audited financial statements with
	the CEO and CFO and then the full Board. The Committee will review the interim
	financial statements with the CEO and CFO. The external auditor will be present
	at these meetings.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Review of CEO and CFO Certification
	Process&#150;In connection with its review of the annual audited financial statements
	and interim financial statements, the Committee will also review the process for
	the CEO and CFO certifications with respect to the financial statements and the
	Corporation&#146;s disclosure and internal controls, including any material
	deficiencies or changes in those controls.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Review of Earnings and Other
	Releases&#150;The Committee will review with the CFO any earnings guidance to be
	issued by the Corporation and any news release containing financial information
	taken from the Corporation&#146;s financial statements prior to the release of the
	financial statements to the public. In addition, the CFO must review with the
	committee the substance of any presentations to analysts or rating agencies that
	contain a change in strategy or outlook.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Approval of Audit and Non-Audit
	Services&#150;In addition to recommending to the Board the external auditor to
	examine the Corporation&#146;s financial statements and the compensation of the
	external auditor for audit services, the Committee must approve any use of that
	external auditor to provide non-audit services prior to its engagement. It is
	the Committee&#146;s practice to restrict the non-audit services that may be provided
	by the external auditor in order to minimize relationships that could appear to
	impair the objectivity of the external auditor.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Hiring Guidelines for Independent
	Auditor Employees&#150;The Committee will adopt guidelines regarding the hiring of
	any partner, employee, reviewing tax professional or other person providing
	audit assurance to the external auditor of the Corporation on any aspect of its
	certification of the Corporation&#146;s financial statements.
</P>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage137"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	NORBORD
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	MANAGEMENT
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Appendix E&#150;Audit Committee&#150;Terms
	of Reference
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	PROXY CIRCULAR
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=3>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="11%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT SIZE=5>
<B>
	52
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="60%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Audit Partner Rotation&#150;The Committee will
	ensure that the lead audit partner assigned by the external auditor to the
	Corporation, as well as the independent review partner charged with reviewing
	the financial statements of the Corporation, are changed at least every five
	years.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	10.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Process for Handling Complaints about
	Accounting Matters&#150;The Committee has established the following procedure for the
	receipt and treatment of any complaint received by the Corporation regarding
	accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing matters:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The Corporation will make available and make
	known special mail and e-mail addresses and telephone numbers for receiving
	complaints regarding accounting, internal accounting controls or auditing
	matters;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Copies of complaints received will be sent to
	the members of the Committee;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; All complaints will be investigated by the
	Corporation&#146;s finance staff, except as otherwise directed by the Committee. The
	Committee may request that outside advisors be retained to investigate any
	complaint; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The status of each complaint will be reported
	on a quarterly basis to the Committee and, if the Committee so directs, to the
	full Board.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	The Corporation&#146;s Code of Business
	Conduct prohibits any Director, officer or employee of the Corporation from
	retaliating or taking any adverse action against anyone for raising or helping
	to resolve a complaint.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Evaluation&#150;The Committee will conduct and
	present to the Board an annual evaluation of the performance of the Committee
	and the adequacy of these terms of reference and recommend any proposed change
	to the Board for approval.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	12.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Other Matters&#150;The Committee will conduct
	reviews and, where appropriate, recommend action by the Board, on:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(a)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; the annual information form to be filed by the
	Corporation;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(b)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; regular reports on outstanding litigation that
	could have a material effect on the Corporation;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an annual certificate of the CEO attesting that
	senior management of the Corporation have received and agreed to be bound by the
	Corporation&#146;s Code of Business Conduct and as to compliance with the Code;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an annual report on officers&#146; expenses;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(e)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an annual report on consulting and legal fees
	paid by the Corporation; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 52PX; TEXT-INDENT: -26PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	(f)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; an annual report on the Corporation&#146;s insurance
	coverage and costs.
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

<FONT SIZE=4>
<P>
<B>
	Appendix F&#150;Reporting Package
</B>
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<P ALIGN=CENTER>
	Change of Auditor Notice
<BR>
</B>
	Pursuant to National Instrument
	51-102, Section 4.11
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On February 28, 2007, Ernst &amp; Young LLP resigned as
	auditors of Norbord Inc. (the "Corporation") at the request of the
	Corporation. KPMG LLP were appointed as auditors of the Corporation to replace
	Ernst &amp; Young LLP. The Audit Committee and the Board of Directors
	participated in and approved the decision to change theauditors.
</P>
<P>
	The auditors&#146; reports of Ernst &amp; Young LLP on the financial statements of
	the Corporation during the period commencing January1, 2005 and ending on
	February28, 2007 did not contain any reservation.
</P>
<P>
	The Corporation is of the opinion that there are no "reportable events" as
	defined in National Instrument51-102.
</P>
<P>
	The Corporation has decided to propose KPMG LLP for appointment as auditor at
	the annual meeting of shareholders to be held on April25,2007.
</P>
<P>
	DATED February28, 2007.
</P>
<P>
	Per:
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
<IMG HEIGHT=76 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SHINET8.GIF" WIDTH=128 BORDER=0>
</P>
<P>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
	John Tremayne
<BR>
	Executive VicePresident and
	Chief Financial Officer
</FONT>
</P>

</P>
<B>
<P>
	Re: Norbord Inc.
<BR>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Change of Auditor
	Notice dated February 28, 2007
</P>
</B>
<P>
	Pursuant to National Instrument51-102 (Part4.11), we have read the
	above-noted Change of Auditor Notice and confirm our agreement with the
	information contained in the Notice.
</P>
<P>
	Yours sincerely,
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
<IMG HEIGHT=61 SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2007/03/26/0001204459-07-000369_SHINET10.GIF" WIDTH=202 BORDER=0>
</P>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<P>
	cc: The Board of Directors, Norbord Inc.
</P>
</FONT>

<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Unless otherwise noted, all
	information contained in this Annual Information Form is as at December 31,
	2006.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	All dollar amounts in this Annual
	Information Form are US dollars unless otherwise specified.
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Parts of the 2006 Annual Report of
	Norbord Inc. for the year ended December 31, 2006 ("Annual Report") are
	incorporated by reference in this Annual Information Form.
</P>
<B>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Caution Regarding Forward-Looking
	Information
</P>
</B>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	This document includes
	forward-looking statements, as defined by applicable securities legislation.
	Often, but not always, forward-looking statements can be identified by the use
	of words such as "believes," "expects" or "does not expect," "is
	expected," "targets," "outlook," "plans," "scheduled," "estimates,"
	"forecasts," "intends," "anticipates" or "does not anticipate" or
	variations of such words and phrases or statements that certain actions, events
	or results "may," "could," "would," "might" or "will" be taken, occur
	or be achieved. Forward-looking statements involve known and unknown risks,
	uncertainties and other factors which may cause the actual results, performance
	or achievements of Norbord to be materially different from any future results,
	performance or achievements expressed or implied by the forward-looking
	statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Examples of such statements include,
	but are not limited to, comments with respect to: (1) outlook for the markets
	for products; (2) expectations regarding future product pricing; (3) the outlook
	for operations; (4) expectations regarding mill capacity and production volumes;
	(5) objectives; (6) strategies to achieve those objectives; (7) expected
	financial results; (8) sensitivity to changes in product prices, such as the
	price of OSB; (9) sensitivity to key input prices, such as the price of natural
	gas; (10) sensitivity to changes in foreign exchange rates; (11) Margin
	Improvement Program targets; (12) expectations regarding income tax rates; (13)
	expectations regarding compliance with environmental regulations; (14)
	expectations regarding contingent liabilities and guarantees, including the
	outcome of pending litigation; and (15) expectations regarding the amount,
	timing and benefits of capital investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Although Norbord believes it has a
	reasonable basis for making these forward-looking statements, readers are
	cautioned not to place undue reliance on such forward-looking information. By
	its nature, forward-looking information involves numerous assumptions, inherent
	risks and uncertainties, both general and specific, which contribute to the
	possibility that the predictions, forecasts and other forward-looking statements
	will not occur. These factors include, but are not limited to: (1) assumptions
	in connection with the economic and financial conditions in the United States,
	Europe, Canada and globally; (2) risks inherent with product concentration; (3)
	effects of competition and product pricing pressures; (4) outcome of the OSB
	class action lawsuits; (5) risks inherent with customer dependence; (6) effects
	of variations in the price and availability of manufacturing inputs including
	continued access to fibre resources at competitive prices; (7) various events
	which could disrupt operations, including natural events and ongoing relations
	with employees; (8) impact of changes to or non-compliance with environmental
	regulations; (9) impact of any product liability claims in excess of insurance
	coverage; (10) risks inherent with a capital intensive industry; (11) impact of
	future outcome of certain tax exposures; and (12) effects of currency exposures
	and exchange rate fluctuations.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The above list of important factors
	affecting forward-looking information is not exhaustive. Additional factors are
	noted elsewhere and reference should be made to the other risks discussed in
	filings with Canadian securities regulatory authorities and the US Securities
	and Exchange Commission. Norbord does not undertake to update any
	forward-looking statements, whether written or oral, that may be made from time
	to time by or on behalf of the Company, whether as a result of new information,
	future events or otherwise, or to publicly update or revise the above list of
	factors affecting this information.
</P>

<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>

</B>

<FONT FACE=ACASLON-REGULAR SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	Corporate Structure
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord Inc. is a corporation existing under the laws of
	Canada. Norbord Inc. was continued by Articles of Amalgamation issued under the
	Canada Business Corporations Act on December 31, 1998. Norbord Inc. filed
	Articles of Arrangement and Restated Articles of Incorporation on June 30, 2004,
	to facilitate the transfer of its paper and timber business to a new public
	company, Fraser Papers Inc. ("Fraser Papers") and the change of its name from
	Nexfor Inc. to Norbord Inc.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The registered and principal office
	of Norbord Inc. is 1 Toronto Street, Suite 600, Toronto, Ontario, M5C 2W4.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In this form, "Norbord" means
	Norbord Inc. and its consolidated subsidiaries and affiliates, and "Company"
	means Norbord Inc. as a separate corporation, unless the context implies
	otherwise.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord is an international producer
	of wood-based panels with approximately 2,800 employees and 16 plant locations
	in the United States, Europe and Canada. Norbord has assets and sales in excess
	of $1 billion, and is one of the world&#146;s largest producers of oriented strand
	board ("OSB").
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At March 1, 2007 Brookfield Asset
	Management Inc., a global asset manager, owned approximately 38% of the
	outstanding Common Shares of the Company. The Company&#146;s Common Shares are traded
	on the TSX under the symbol NBD.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The principal operating subsidiaries
	of the Company are:
</P>
</FONT>

<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	General Development of the Business
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord has made substantial changes in its business over the
	past three years by increasing its investment in the panelboard business and
	eliminating its investments in lumber, pulp, timber and papers. On June 30,
	2004, Norbord achieved a major milestone in this strategy when it distributed to
	its common shareholders all of the common shares of Fraser Papers, a corporation
	formed to acquire Norbord&#146;s remaining lumber, pulp, timber and paper
	assets.
</P>
</EFX_GENERAL_DEVELOPMENT_OF_THE_COMPANY>
<I>
<B>
<EFX_BUSINESS>
<A NAME="FIS_BUSINESS"></A>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Changes in the Business 2004-2006
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In December 2006, Norbord started up the second line at its
	Cordele, Georgia OSB mill. Construction began in June 2005. The project cost was
	$135 million, and when fully ramped up will add 550 million square feet (
<SUP>
	3/
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
</SUP>
	-inch basis) of production capacity, increasing
	Norbord&#146;s North American OSB capacity by 15%.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In December 2006, Norbord
	indefinitely shut its Juniper, New Brunswick I-Joist facility. The mill has an
	annual capacity of 60 million lineal feet. A provision of $13 million was
	recorded in the Company&#146;s 2006 consolidated financial statements related to this
	closure.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On July 14, 2006, the Company paid
	$128 million to shareholders in a special CAD $1.00 per common share
	dividend.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On May 20, 2005, the Company paid
	$118 million to shareholders in a special CAD $1.00 per common share
	dividend.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Also on May 20, 2005, the Company
	redeemed CAD $60 million of Class A Preferred Shares Series 1 at par ($25.00),
	plus accrued and unpaid dividends.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In September 2004, Norbord acquired
	an OSB and particleboard facility in Genk, Belgium for $64 million. The
	acquisition positioned Norbord as one of the largest producers of OSB in Europe
	with an approximate 20% market share.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On September 30, 2004, the Company
	paid $149 million to shareholders in a special CAD $1.00 per common share
	dividend.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In July 2004, Norbord redeemed its
	$200 million 6
<SUP>
	7/
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due in 2005 and recorded a
	pre-tax charge of $9 million for call premiums net of associated interest rate
	swap gains.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In June 2004, the Company changed its
	name from Nexfor Inc. and distributed its remaining lumber, pulp, timber and
	paper assets to its shareholders in the form of a separate publicly traded
	corporation, Fraser Papers. The distribution was facilitated by distributing
	Fraser Papers common shares to common shareholders of Norbord, on the basis of
	one common share of Fraser Papers for every five common shares of Norbord
	held.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In March 2004, Norbord acquired
	MeadWestvaco Corporation&#146;s 50% interest in Norbord Minnesota Inc. for $34
	million, including $6 million of working capital. Norbord Minnesota Inc. was
	previously owned jointly by Norbord and MeadWestvaco Corporation.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Outlook
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	For information regarding Norbord&#146;s outlook, see Norbord&#146;s
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis in the Company&#146;s 2006 Annual
	Report.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>

	Risks of the Business
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">

<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	Risks of the Business
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Information on Norbord&#146;s business risks is included in the
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis in the Company&#146;s 2006 Annual Report.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The principal risks to Norbord&#146;s
	businesses include those that would be generally expected of an international,
	capital-intensive manufacturing business. They include:
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Product Concentration
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	OSB accounts for more than 75% of Norbord&#146;s panel production
	capacity. The price of OSB is one of the most volatile in the wood-based panels
	industry. Norbord&#146;s concentration in OSB increases its sensitivity to product
	pricing and will result in a high degree of sales and earnings
	volatility.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Product Prices
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s financial performance is principally dependent on the
	selling price of its products. The markets for most of Norbord&#146;s products are
	highly cyclical and are characterized by periods of supply and demand imbalance
	during which its product prices have tended to fluctuate significantly. In
	addition, since many of Norbord&#146;s products are used for new home construction,
	seasonal and annual weather changes can affect demand and sales volumes. These
	imbalances, which may affect different areas of Norbord&#146;s business at different
	times, are influenced by numerous factors that are beyond Norbord&#146;s control and
	include: changes in global and regional production capacity for a particular
	product or group of products; changes in the end-use of those products or the
	increased use of substitute products; and the overall level of economic activity
	in the regions in which Norbord conducts business. Norbord has been negatively
	affected in the past by declines in product pricing and has occasionally taken
	market-related production downtime.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Competition
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The wood-based panels industry is a highly competitive business
	environment in which companies compete, to a large degree, on the basis of
	price. Norbord&#146;s principal market is the United States where it competes with
	North American and, in some instances, foreign producers. Norbord&#146;s European
	operations compete primarily with other European producers. Certain competitors
	may have lower-cost facilities than Norbord. Norbord&#146;s ability to compete in
	these and other markets is dependent on a variety of factors such as
	manufacturing costs, free access to markets, customer service, product quality,
	financial resources, and currency exchange rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In addition, competitors could
	develop new cost-effective substitutes for Norbord&#146;s wood-based panels, or
	building codes could be changed to make the use of Norbord&#146;s products less
	attractive for certain applications.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Customer Dependence
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord sells its products primarily to major retail chains,
	contractor supply yards, and wholesale distributors and faces strong competition
	for the business of significant customers. Although no single customer accounts
	for more than 10% of Norbord&#146;s sales, Norbord generally does not have
	contractual assurances as to future sales. As a result, any significant customer
	order cancellations could negatively affect Norbord&#146;s sales and earnings.
	Continued consolidation in the retail industry could expose Norbord to increased
	concentration of customer dependence and increase customers&#146; ability to exert
	pricing pressure on Norbord.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage151"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">

<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Risks
	of the Business
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">

</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=6>
	7
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Manufacturing Inputs
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord is exposed to commodity price risk on most of its
	manufacturing inputs, principally wood fibre, resin and energy. These
	manufacturing inputs are purchased primarily on the open market in competition
	with other users of such resources and prices are influenced by factors beyond
	Norbord&#146;s control. Norbord may not be able to pass increased costs through to
	its customers.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Fibre Resource
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The market for wood fibre is highly competitive. A significant
	portion of Norbord&#146;s wood fibre requirements in Canada are met through timber
	supply and forest management agreements and sustainable forest licenses ("Crown
	Arrangements") with Canadian provincial governmental authorities
	("Governmental Authorities"). These Crown Arrangements, among other things,
	require the payment of stumpage fees for timber harvested and compliance with
	specified rehabilitation and silviculture management practices, cover periods
	ranging from 20 to 25 years and may be renewed or extended for additional
	five-year periods. These Crown Arrangements could be revoked or cancelled for
	non-performance. The Crown Arrangements also contain terms and conditions which
	could, under limited circumstances, result in a reduction of annual allowable
	timber that may be harvested by Norbord without any compensation. Restrictions
	on harvesting have increased over the past several years. Canadian aboriginal
	groups have made claims in respect of land governed by Governmental Authorities,
	which could affect a portion of these Crown Arrangements. Settlements in respect
	of these claims could increase the cost to harvest timber on such land and could
	lower the volume of timber available to Norbord.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In the United States, Europe and
	Canada, Norbord purchases timber, wood chips and other wood residues as well as
	recycled materials on the open market in competition with other users of such
	wood fibre resources and prices are influenced by factors beyond Norbord&#146;s
	control.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Litigation
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord and eight other North American OSB producers have been
	named as defendants in several lawsuits filed in the United States District
	Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The lawsuits allege that these
	nine North American OSB producers violated United States and various state
	antitrust and other laws by allegedly agreeing to fix prices and reduce the
	supply of OSB from June 1, 2002 through the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The named plaintiffs seek to have the
	cases certified as class actions. One group of plaintiffs seeks to certify a
	class of persons and entities that purchased OSB in the United States directly
	from any of the named North American OSB producers between June 1, 2002 and the
	present. Other plaintiffs seek to certify one or more classes of persons and
	entities that purchased OSB in various states and the District of Columbia
	indirectly between June1, 2002 and the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord believes that the lawsuits
	are entirely without merit and intends to defend this matter vigorously.
	However, the lawsuits are in their early stages, the outcome of litigation is
	subject to inherent uncertainties and an adverse outcome to these litigations
	has the potential to materially and adversely affect Norbord&#146;s business,
	financial condition and results of operations.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Labour Relations
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s US employees are non-unionized, while its UK, Belgian
	and most of its Canadian employees are unionized, representing just under
	one-half of the workforce. All but one of Norbord&#146;s UK and Belgian union
	contracts are evergreen. Norbord&#146;s Cowie and Canadian contracts typically cover
	a three- to five-year term. No
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=3>
	l
</FONT>
	abour
	union contracts expired in 2006 and contracts covering employees at our
	Val-d&#146;Or, Quebec, and Cochrane, Ontario mills expire during 2007. Norbord
	believes it will be able to negotiate acceptable contracts upon expiry, but
	strikes or work stoppages could result if Norbord is unable to do so.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;

</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Environmental Matters
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s operations are subject to a range of general and
	industry-specific environmental laws and regulations relating to air emissions,
	wastewater discharges, solid and hazardous waste management, plant and wildlife
	protection and site remediation. Norbord believes that all of its facilities are
	in substantial compliance with these matters. Failure to comply with applicable
	environmental laws and regulations could result in fines, penalties or other
	enforcement actions that could impact Norbord&#146;s production capacity or increase
	Norbord&#146;s production costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In January 2005 the International
	Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) reclassified formaldehyde as a known human
	carcinogen. Norbord&#146;s products are tested to ensure that they comply with agreed
	standards for formaldehyde content and emissions from the product. The emission
	of formaldehyde from OSB panels is similar to the emissions of natural wood.
	Standards for its other products are well below the levels associated with any
	observed health effects and Norbord believes there is no material risk
	associated with the use of formaldehyde in its manufacturing process.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Product Liability
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord produces a variety of wood-based panels. Norbord is not
	currently subject to any material claims with respect to the fitness for use of
	its products or related to product quality or performance issues. Norbord
	retains commercially reasonable insurance coverage for such claims, but could
	face increased costs if any future claims exceed purchased insurance
	coverage.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Natural Events
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s business is exposed to numerous natural events such
	as forest fires, adverse weather conditions, insect infestation, disease,
	prolonged drought, and other natural disasters, which are not insurable events.
	If such an event occurs, Norbord may need to curtail production or incur
	increased fibre costs.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Capital Intensity
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The production of wood-based panels is capital intensive.
	Although Norbord maintains its production equipment with regular periodic and
	scheduled maintenance, there can be no assurance that key pieces of equipment
	will not need to be repaired or replaced. In certain circumstances, the costs of
	repairing or replacing that equipment and the associated downtime of the
	affected production line may not be an insurable event.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Tax Exposures
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord maintains reserves for known estimated tax exposures in
	all jurisdictions. These exposures are settled primarily through the closure of
	audits with the jurisdictional taxing authorities. Norbord believes its reserves
	are adequate to cover such exposures, but future settlements could differ
	materially from such reserves.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Currency Exposures
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord reports its financial results in US dollars. A portion
	of Norbord&#146;s product prices and costs are influenced by relative currency values
	(particularly the Canadian dollar, Pound Sterling and Euro). Significant
	fluctuations in relative currency values could negatively affect the cost
	competitiveness of Norbord&#146;s facilities, the value of its foreign investments,
	the results of its operations and its financial position. Norbord&#146;s policy is to
	hedge all significant balance sheet exposures. In addition, the Company may
	hedge a portion of its foreign currency-denominated cash flow exposures.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

	Proceedings
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>

	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=6>
	9
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	Legal Proceedings
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord and eight other North American OSB producers have been
	named as defendants in several lawsuits filed in the United States District
	Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The lawsuits allege that these
	nine North American OSB producers violated United States and various state
	antitrust and other laws by allegedly agreeing to fix prices and reduce the
	supply of OSB from June 1, 2002 through the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The named plaintiffs seek to have the
	cases certified as class actions. One group of plaintiffs seeks to certify a
	class of persons and entities that purchased OSB in the United States directly
	from any of the named North American OSB producers between June 1, 2002 and the
	present. Other plaintiffs seek to certify one or more classes of persons and
	entities that purchased OSB in various states and the District of Columbia
	indirectly between June 1, 2002 and the present.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord believes that the lawsuits
	are entirely without merit and intends to defend this matter vigorously.
	However, the lawsuits are in their early stages, the outcome of litigation is
	subject to inherent uncertainties and an adverse outcome to these litigations
	has the potential to materially and adversely affect Norbord&#146;s business,
	financial condition and results of operations.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage154"></A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	Description of the Business
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">

<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	Description of the Business
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=LEFT>
	Principal Products
</P>
</B>
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s business comprises the manufacturing, sales,
	marketing and distribution of panelboards and related products used primarily in
	the construction of new homes or the renovation and repair of existing
	structures. Products are generally sold to major retail chains, contractor
	supply yards and wholesale distributors. Some mill products move directly to
	industrial customers for further processing or as components for other
	products.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=LEFT>
	In 2006 and 2005, Norbord sales
	originated as follows:
</P>
</FONT>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="80%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	2006
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	2005
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	North
	America
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%" BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	66%
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%" BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	74%
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="80%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Europe
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	34%
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="10%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	26%
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s production includes OSB, MDF, particleboard, hardwood
	plywood, and related specialty products. OSB is used principally for roofing,
	flooring and wall sheathing in home construction. OSB has displaced softwood
	plywood in many structural end-uses. OSB production currently represents
	approximately 62% of total North American structural panel production. In
	Europe, OSB&#146;s share of the structural panel market is lower than in North
	America due mainly to different housing construction methods. However, OSB use
	is growing rapidly in Europe. In North America, OSB is a low-cost substitute for
	plywood. In Europe, OSB is often a high performance substitute for
	particleboard.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s particleboard is used
	primarily in flooring and other construction applications. MDF applications
	include cabinets, moldings, interior wall paneling and furniture. Norbord&#146;s
	hardwood plywood is overlaid with veneers and has similar end-uses to MDF.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord employs multi-opening press technology at its
	Minnesota, Georgia, Mississippi, and two Texas OSB mills in the United States.
	All of these mills purchase their wood fibre requirements from outside sources
	with prices based on regional market dynamics. These mills are not unionized and
	employees participate in profit sharing programs whereby a percentage of each
	mill&#146;s operating income is shared equally with the employee group at that
	mill.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord also employs multi-opening
	press technology at its two Quebec OSB mills in Canada. A significant portion of
	the production of these mills is concentrated on specialty panels including
	I-joist web stock, thin panels and flooring. The wood fibre requirements for
	these mills are obtained under 25-year timber supply and forest management
	agreements with the Quebec Government and also from other outside sources with
	prices based on regional market dynamics. The mills are unionized.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>
<A NAME="eolPage156"></A>
<P STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: ALWAYS">
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Annual
<BR>
	Information
<BR>
	Form
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Description of the
	Business
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=RIGHT WIDTH="19%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
	12
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord employs continuous press
	technology at its South Carolina and Alabama OSB mills in the US. Continuous
	press technology allows for improved operational efficiency and the production
	of OSB in non-standard sizes and with specialized performance characteristics.
	These mills purchase their wood fibre requirements from outside sources with
	prices based on regional market dynamics. These mills are not unionized and
	employees participate in profit sharing programs whereby a percentage of each
	mill&#146;s operating income is shared equally with the employee group at that
	mill.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s mill in Cowie, Scotland is
	a large, integrated operation with a continuous press MDF production line, a
	continuous press particleboard line, and value-added laminating facilities. The
	South Molton, England particleboard mill employs single-opening press technology
	and is integrated with laminating operations and a flat-pack furniture
	manufacturing facility. The OSB mill in Inverness, Scotland employs two
	multi-opening press lines. All of Norbord&#146;s mills in the UK purchase their wood
	fibre requirements from outside sources with prices based on regional market
	dynamics.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Genk, Belgium facility, acquired
	in September 2004, has two independent production lines which manufacture OSB
	and particleboard. The OSB line started up in 2001 and employs continuous press
	technology. The particleboard line started up in 1991 and employs multi-opening
	press technology. The wood fibre for the Genk operation is a combination of
	roundwood for OSB and recycled wood (pre and post-consumer), mixed roundwood and
	flax fibre for the particleboard line. Wood fibre purchases are made on the open
	market from a combination of public and private enterprises in the region.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Deposit, New York mill produces
	MDF from hardwood fibre and is the only facility of its kind in the northeastern
	US. The Cochrane, Ontario plywood mill produces hardwood overlay
	plywood.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Fibre Resource
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	For the most part, Norbord&#146;s operations purchase wood fibre in
	the form of logs, wood chips and wood residues from outside sources.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In addition to sourcing their wood
	fibre from third parties, Norbord&#146;s Canadian operations hold forestry licenses
	to source 880,000 cubic metres of poplar and birch under Crown Arrangements in
	Ontario and Quebec. These provincial licenses generally include provisions for
	ground rents, stumpage charges and reforestation and are granted for terms of 20
	to 25 years with renewal provisions. Restrictions on harvesting have increased
	over the past several years. In Quebec, the Chief Forester released the maximum
	annual allowable cut (MAAC) recommendations for the period 2008-2013. The MAAC
	on Norbord&#146;s licenses will be reduced by 20% for aspen. All but 3% of this loss
	will be offset by access to more birch and to over-mature aspen stands.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord participates in the
<I>
	Sustainable Forestry Initiative
</I>
	(SFI) forest certification program. To
	obtain certification, mills must demonstrate a commitment to forest conservation
	including sound management planning and the protection of wildlife habitats and
	water quality. Nine of Norbord&#146;s North American operations have received SFI
	forest certification. In addition, the Cochrane plywood mill was certified
	"FSC-mixed" under the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) Chain of Custody
	certification in 2006.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In Europe, all sites hold FSC Chain
	of Custody certification, which assures that raw materials from sustainably
	managed resources are tracked through to the final product. Accordingly, a
	portion of the European mills&#146; production is labeled with the FSC
	stamp.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Research and Development
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord carries out research and applied technology programs to
	improve production techniques and product quality, develop new products, and
	minimize the environmental impact of its operations. The Company operates a
	central laboratory facility in St. Laurent, Quebec. In addition, the Company
	participates in and performs contract work at a number of industry-wide
	organizations including Forintek and the Forest Engineering Institute of
	Canada.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>

<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Environment, Health and Safety
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord&#146;s Environment Policy and Health and Safety Policy are
	attached as Appendices A and B respectively to this document.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord measures its performance
	against environment, health and safety targets in four areas: 1) injury
	frequency and severity; 2) environmental compliance; 3) impact minimization; and
	4) environment, health and safety management systems. Norbord continues its
	program of auditing its operations on a regular schedule to ensure continuing
	high standards of performance.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Maximum Achievable Control Technology
	(MACT) regulations, designed to reduce hazardous air emissions, were introduced
	in the US in 2004. The new standards apply to more than 200 mills manufacturing
	plywood, OSB, MDF, particleboard and other wood composite panels. Existing mills
	are required to demonstrate compliance by October 2008.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2004 and 2005, $29 million in
	emission control equipment was installed at the Nacogdoches, Bemidji and Deposit
	mills to meet state requirements and increase production. With these
	investments, the Company believes that all US mills with the exception of the
	original Cordele line meet the compliance requirements of the MACT standards.
	Where necessary, permit applications will be submitted in 2007 to finalize
	compliance requirements. In 2008, a capital investment of approximately $8
	million may be required to bring the original Cordele line into compliance.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A separate MACT regulation has been
	approved to control the emissions of hazardous air pollutants from industrial
	boilers. Six Norbord operations are affected by these regulations. Capital
	requirements to meet the compliance deadline of September 2007 are not expected
	to be material.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In Europe, regulations to control the
	risks of fire and explosion came into force in 2004 (the UK&#146;s Dangerous
	Substances and Explosive Atmosphere Regulations (DSEAR) and Europe&#146;s Explosive
	Atmosphere (ATEX) Directive). In the UK, most compliance work was completed in
	2006, with final minor upgrades scheduled in early 2007. In Genk, compliance
	work began in 2006 and will be completed during 2007 and 2008. To date, the
	Company&#146;s European operations have invested approximately $6 million in
	equipment and controls to comply with the regulations.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Kyoto Accord has been ratified in
	Canada and Europe. The US government chose not to ratify the Accord, but rather
	to determine its own greenhouse gas reduction targets. Canada has not yet
	finalized regulations to meet Canada&#146;s Kyoto goals; however, as relatively small
	consumers of fossil fuels it is unlikely that Norbord&#146;s Canadian operations will
	be affected by regulations. All of Norbord&#146;s operations in the UK entered into
	Kyoto climate change energy efficiency agreements in 2002, which has to-date
	resulted in over &#163;10 million tax and energy efficiency cost savings. A "cap and
	trade" carbon trading scheme was rolled out across Europe in 2005 which has
	established energy efficiency targets for Norbord&#146;s Genk mill and the Cowie MDF
	plant. Opportunities for improved energy efficiency and completion of the
	biomass heat energy systems in 2007 will benefit the Genk and Cowie mills&#146;
	ability to comply with energy efficiency targets and avoid the need to acquire
	carbon credits.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Human Resources
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord employs approximately 2,800 people at its operations in
	the US, Europe and Canada. Just under one-half of these employees are
	represented by labour unions. Its corporate head office is in Toronto,
	Canada.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company negotiated a three-year
	collective agreement with the Teamsters, Quebec Union effective January 1, 2005
	at its Val-d&#146;Or, Quebec OSB mill. This contract expires in December
	2007.
</P>
</FONT>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

	expires on June 30, 2009.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The United Steelworkers Union
	represents employees at the Cochrane plywood mill. A five-year agreement was
	settled in November 2002. The Company will renegotiate the contract which
	expires on May 31, 2007.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Substantially all of the hourly
	employees at the Company&#146;s European operations are represented by various trade
	organizations. The agreements covering employees in Europe, other than Cowie,
	have no expiry date. The employees of the Cowie mill are represented by the
	Transport &amp; General Workers and Amicus unions under three-year contracts
	effective April 2005. The Company will renegotiate these contracts upon expiry
	March 31, 2008.
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
</FONT>
</B>
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In October 2005, Norbord announced a Normal Course Issuer Bid
	to buy back up to 9.0 million common shares representing 10% of the public float
	of Common Shares of Norbord. The Company completed the purchase and cancellation
	of 2.7 million Common Shares under the bid. The bid expired on November 1, 2006
	and Norbord did not renew the bid.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On February 14, 2007, Norbord closed
	the issuance of $200 million 6.45% senior unsecured notes. Proceeds from the
	notes will be used to repay Norbord&#146;s $200 million 8
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	1/
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due March 20, 2008. Pending such
	use, the proceeds will be invested in investment grade fixed income securities
	and short-term money market securities.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2005, Norbord repurchased and
	cancelled $10 million of its 7
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	1/
<SUB>
	4
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due in 2012. The premium paid on
	repurchase was offset by the recognition of gains on the associated interest
	rate swaps.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Norbord has committed unsecured
	revolving bank lines of $200 million which mature in 2010. As of March 1, 2007,
	$59 million of these lines were utilized&#150;$55 million drawn as cash and $4
	million drawn as letters of credit&#150;with the balance available to support
	short-term liquidity requirements.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On May 20, 2005 the Company redeemed
	all of its Class A Preferred Shares Series 1 at par ($25.00), plus accrued and
	unpaid dividends.
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<I>
	Description of Share Capital
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The authorized share capital of Norbord consists of an
	unlimited number of Class A Preferred Shares, an unlimited number of Class B
	Preferred Shares, an unlimited number of Non-Voting Participating Shares and an
	unlimited number of Common Shares. As of March 1, 2007 there were 143,864,581
	Common Shares outstanding.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following is a summary of the
	principal attributes of the Common Shares, the Class A Preferred Shares, the
	Class B Preferred Shares and the Non-Voting Participating Shares of
	Norbord.
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<HR COLOR=#000000 SIZE=5>

	Annual

	Information
<BR>
	Form
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=6>
	16
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>

<FONT FACE=SELSWW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Common Shares
</P>
</I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The holders of Common Shares are
	entitled to one vote per share at all meetings of shareholders. They are
	entitled to receive dividends if, as and when declared by the Directors ratably
	with any holders of the Non-Voting Participating Shares, subject to the
	attributes of each series of Non-Voting Participating Shares. In the event of
	any liquidation, dissolution or winding up, subject to the rights of holders of
	Class A Preferred Shares and any Class B Preferred Shares, the holders of Common
	Shares are entitled to participate ratably with any holders of Non-Voting
	Participating Shares in any distribution of the assets of Norbord, subject to
	the attributes of each series of Non-Voting Participating Shares.
</P>
<I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Class A Preferred Shares
</P>
</I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Class A Preferred Shares are
	issuable in series. The Directors of Norbord are empowered to fix the number of
	shares in and the designation and attributes of each series, which may include
	voting rights. The Class A Preferred Shares will be entitled to priority over
	the Class B Preferred Shares, the Non-voting Participating Shares and the Common
	Shares with respect to the payment of dividends and the distribution of assets
	of Norbord in the event of any liquidation, dissolution or winding up of
	Norbord.
</P>
<I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Class B Preferred Shares
</P>
</I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Class B Preferred Shares are
	issuable in series. The Directors of Norbord are empowered to fix the number of
	shares in and the designation and attributes of each series, which may include
	voting rights. The Class B Preferred Shares are entitled to priority over the
	Non-Voting Participating Shares and the Common Shares with respect to the
	payment of dividends and the distribution of assets of Norbord in the event of
	any liquidation, dissolution or winding up of Norbord.
</P>
<I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Non-Voting Participating
	Shares
</P>
</I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Non-Voting Participating Shares
	are issuable in series. The Directors of Norbord are empowered to fix the number
	of shares in and the designation and attributes of each series, which may
	include a preferential dividend or a priority in any distribution of assets of
	Norbord. Subject thereto, the holders of Non-Voting Participating Shares are
	entitled to receive dividends if, as and when declared by the Directors ratably
	with the holders of Common Shares and, in the event of any liquidation,
	dissolution or winding up, subject to the rights of the holders of Class A
	Preferred Shares and any Class B Preferred Shares, to participate ratably with
	the holders of Common Shares in any distribution of the assets of
	Norbord.
</P>
<I>
<B>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Description of Debt
	Securities
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At December 31, 2006, Norbord had
	issued and outstanding senior unsecured public debentures as follows:
</P>
<UL>
<LI>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 20PX; TEXT-INDENT: -10PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp; $200
	million of 8
<SUP>
	1/
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due March 20, 2008.
</P>
<LI>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 20PX; TEXT-INDENT: -10PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp; $240
	million of 7
<SUP>
	1/
<SUB>
	4
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due July 1, 2012.
</P>
</LI>
</UL>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX; TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On February 14,
	2007, Norbord issued $200 million of 6.45% senior unsecured notes due February
	15, 2017. The proceeds will be used to repay Norbord&#146;s $200 million
	8
<SUP>
	1/
<SUB>
	8
</SUB>
</SUP>
	% debentures due March 20, 2008.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 30PX; TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Interest is
	payable semi-annually and the debt securities may be redeemed at Norbord&#146;s
	option at any time at specified redemption prices.
</P>
</FONT>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P>
	Credit Ratings
</P>
</FONT>
</B>
<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON>
<FONT FACE=EZFLHW+ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following table summarizes the credit ratings accorded to
	Norbord&#146;s senior unsecured debt securities by the following rating
	agencies:
</P>
</FONT>
</FONT>
<B>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE: COLLAPSE" BORDERCOLOR=#111111 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0 WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="80%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Rating
	Agency
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Rating
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 3PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<B>
	Outlook
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s Ratings Services, Inc.
	("S&amp;P")
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10 BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	BBB
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-TOP: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10 BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Negative
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="80%">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Moody&#146;s Investors
	Service, Inc. ("Moody&#146;s")
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH=10>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Baa3
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH=10>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Negative
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="80%" BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	DBRS Limited ("DBRS")
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10 BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	BBB
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH=10 BGCOLOR="#E6EACC">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Stable
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</B>
</FONT>
</I>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Credit ratings are intended to
	provide investors with an independent measure of credit quality of any issue of
	securities. The credit ratings accorded to debt securities by the rating
	agencies are not recommendations to purchase, hold or sell the debt securities
	as such ratings do not comment as to market price or suitability for a
	particular investor. There is no assurance that any rating will remain in effect
	for any given period of time or that any rating will not be revised or withdrawn
	entirely by a rating agency in the future if, in its judgement, circumstances so
	warrant.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	S&amp;P credit ratings are on a
	long-term debt rating scale that ranges from AAA to D, which represents the
	range from highest to lowest quality of such securities rated. According to
	S&amp;P, the BBB rating is the fourth highest of ten major categories, and debt
	securities rated BBB exhibit adequate protection parameters. However, adverse
	economic conditions or changing circumstances are more likely to lead to a
	weakened capacity of the obligor to meet its financial commitments on the
	securities. The ratings from AA to CCC may be modified by the addition of a plus
	(+) or minus (
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=DOBUDG+ACASLON SIZE=3>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	.) sign to show relative standing within the major
	rating categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Moody&#146;s credit ratings are on a
	long-term debt rating scale that ranges from Aaa to C, which represents the
	range from highest to lowest quality of such securities rated. According to
	Moody&#146;s, a rating of Baa is the fourth highest of nine major categories, and
	debt securities rated Baa are subject to moderate credit risk. They are
	considered medium-grade and as such may possess certain speculative
	characteristics. Moody&#146;s applies numerical modifiers 1, 2 and 3 in each generic
	rating classification from Aa through Caa. The modifier 1 indicates that the
	security ranks in the higher end of its generic rating category, the modifier 2
	indicates a mid-range ranking and the modifier 3 indicates a ranking in the
	lower end of that generic rating category.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	DBRS credit ratings are on a
	long-term debt rating scale that ranges from AAA to D, which represents the
	range from highest to lowest quality of such securities rated. According to
	DBRS, a rating of BBB is the fourth highest of ten major categories, and debt
	securities rated BBB are of adequate credit quality. Protection of interest and
	principal is considered acceptable, but the entity is fairly susceptible to
	adverse changes in financial and economic conditions, or there may be other
	adverse conditions present which reduce the strength of the entity and its rated
	securities. Rating categories AA through CC are denoted by the subcategories
	"high" and "low". The absence of either a "high" or "low" designation
	indicates the rating is in the "middle" of the category.
</P>
</FONT>
<B>
<I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</I>
</B>
</FONT>

<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>

</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=5>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Dividends
</P>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company has paid quarterly cash dividends of CAD$0.10 per
	Common Share since the fourth quarter of 1990. In addition, the Company paid
	three special dividends of CAD$1.00 on September 30, 2004 to shareholders of
	record on September 20, 2004, on May 20, 2005 to shareholders of record on May
	2, 2005 and on July 14, 2006 to shareholders of record on June 30, 2006. The
	Company has a dividend reinvestment plan whereby shareholders resident in Canada
	can elect to receive their Common Share dividend in Common Shares.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As a result of the Articles of
	Arrangement filed on June 30, 2004 by Norbord, Common Shares of Fraser Papers
	were distributed to the Company&#146;s shareholders of record as of July 2, 2004.
	Norbord Common Shareholders received one Common Share of Fraser Papers for every
	five Common Shares held of Norbord.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	While dividends on Common Shares are
	declared at the discretion of the Board of Directors, it is management&#146;s
	objective to operate the business in a manner that would allow the Board to
	declare a steady quarterly dividend over the business cycle.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The table below summarizes the total
	dividends on Common Shares declared by the Board of Directors, the amounts paid
	out in cash and the amounts distributed as shares under the dividend
	reinvestment plan for the preceding three financial years.
</P>
</FONT>

<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	&nbsp;

<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<P>
	Market for Securities
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company&#146;s Common Shares are listed for trading on the TSX
	under the symbol NBD. On May 20, 2005, all of the Company&#146;s outstanding Class A
	Preferred Shares Series 1 were redeemed at par.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-INDENT: 30PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In 2006, the Company&#146;s Common Shares
	traded in a range between CAD$7.71 and CAD$12.89 per share, ending the year at
	CAD$8.91. Average daily volume traded during the year was 472,047
	shares.
</P>

<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=5>
<EFX_NAME_AND_TITLE>
<A NAME="FIS_NAME_AND_TITLE"></A>
<P>
	Directors and Officers
</P>
<P>
	&nbsp;
</P>
</FONT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
<I>
<B>
<P>
	Directors
</P>
</B>
</I>
<P ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Directors of the Company are set out below. They hold
	office until the next annual meeting of shareholders or until their successors
	are elected or appointed. Norbord&#146;s Board does not have an executive committee.
	Members of the Board&#146;s committees are noted.
</P>
</FONT>

<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: 1PX SOLID" WIDTH="68%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-RIGHT: 26PX" ALIGN=RIGHT>
<FONT FACE=ACASLON SIZE=2>
	Directors and Officers
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="32%" COLSPAN=2>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
<FONT FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE=2>
	Annual
<BR>
	Information
<BR>
	Form
</FONT>
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="68%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: 1PX SOLID; BORDER-BOTTOM: 1PX SOLID" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT: 26PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-TOP: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-LEFT: MEDIUM NONE; BORDER-BOTTOM: MEDIUM NONE" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH="16%">
	&nbsp;
